    Developments in Individual OECD and Selected Non-Member Economies

    Australia

    Output growth will gradually strengthen towards 3% in 2017. Adjustment to declining resource-sector investment will continue. Growth in the non-resource sector will pick up, aided by dollar depreciation and a steady increase in household consumption. Further falls in the rate of unemployment are not expected to generate strong inflationary pressures and will help reduce inequality.

    With receding risks from the housing boom, there is leeway for further monetary policy easing in the event of a new downturn. Close vigilance on housing-market developments is still required. Fiscal consolidation should be back-loaded in light of economic uncertainties. Tax reform should be a core element of structural policy.

    Boosting productivity in Australia requires a focus on innovation. Targeted R&D policy, university-business linkages and effectiveness and efficiency of financial support for research are important. Ensuring strong competition, regulation that accommodates new internet-platform-based businesses, sound ICT infrastructure and continuing education reform are also key for productivity performance. In addition, education reform will boost inclusiveness through stronger low-end skills and better ICT infrastructure can reduce gaps in economic opportunity by improving access in rural areas.

    Rebalancing away from resource sectors continues

    Resource-sector investment and employment face ongoing decline and commodity prices remain low, although new liquefied-natural-gas (LNG) production is boosting exports. Non-resource activity continues to pick up, especially in services exports, in part reflecting past depreciation of the currency. Non-resource activity is now driving employment growth. In addition, house-price and mortgage-credit growth are slowing, assisted by macro-prudential tightening. Consumer price inflation remains low. Also, uncertainty about global economic prospects is impacting Australia’s stock market and business sentiment.

    Economic rebalancing and housing market

    Data are smoothed to reduce the impact of the irregular component of the seasonally adjusted series.

    Australian Bureau of Statistics; OECD Analytical House Price database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367620

    Continued policy support for economic adjustment and productivity growth is required

    The Reserve Bank reduced the policy rate by 25 basis points in May to 1.75%, the first rate change in 12 months, prompting a depreciation of the exchange rate. The projection envisages no further easing and assumes that policy-rate increases begin in 2017. Nevertheless, room for further rate cuts remains in the event of below-par growth. Fiscal policy needs to let the automatic stabilisers operate while keeping a medium-term objective of reducing the public-debt burden.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369200

    In structural policy, the OECD has long emphasised the scope for improving Australia’s tax system, in particular through greater use of efficient tax bases, such as the Goods and Services Tax and land tax, and reforms in specific areas, such as the taxation of pensions (superannuation). Reform to the latter could lower inequality by narrowing differences across households and between women and men among older cohorts. Strengthening of consumer-protection regulation in banking would also benefit households. Australia’s greenhouse-gas reduction policy relies principally on the Emission Reduction Fund, which provides financial incentives for businesses to reduce emissions and as of July 2016 it will backed by a safeguard mechanism that discourages offsetting emissions.

    Boosting productivity requires strengthening capacities for generating and absorbing innovation. Research collaboration between the university and business sectors remains a point of weakness. Also, ensuring value-for-money in financial incentives, such as R&D tax breaks, remains a challenge. Policy responses to disruptive internet-platform innovations have generally been positive. Australian product and labour market regulation is broadly conducive to resource re-allocation, thus helping innovation via creative destruction. However, ICT infrastructure and services require ongoing policy attention and there is scope for greater innovation in public services.

    The pick-up in growth will be gradual, but risks and uncertainties remain sizeable

    Output growth is projected to be just under 3% in 2017. Negative effects from shrinking mining investment are set to ease and new LNG production will boost exports. Exchange rate depreciation and supportive macroeconomic policy have helped rebalance activity towards non-mining sectors. Employment growth will drive a further decline in the rate of unemployment. Household consumption is expected to remain solid, helped by further erosion of the household savings ratio. The pick-up in activity will not generate significant inflationary pressure, due to remaining economic slack.

    Australia’s exposure to commodity-market developments, particularly those linked to the Chinese economy remains an important source of uncertainty and risk. Domestically, the unwinding of housing-market tensions to date may presage dramatic and destabilising developments, rather than herald a soft landing. Uncertainties on future economic policy ahead of the Federal election, which is scheduled for 2nd July, are also adding a degree of risk.

    Austria

    A gradual recovery is underway. For the first time since 2011, growth is projected to exceed 1% in 2016 and to strengthen further in 2017. The recent tax reform will boost private consumption. Investment growth has turned positive and is expected to strengthen further on the back of historically low interest rates and low oil prices.

    Completing orderly wind-downs of failed banks is important to revive confidence, reduce the financial links between banks and the public sector, and strengthen the banking sector. Remaining subsidies to early retirement should be eliminated to raise employment of the elderly, especially women, closer to the OECD average. Rapid integration of migrants in the labour market would entail benefits for social cohesion, growth and Austria's fiscal position.

    Labour productivity growth has varied considerably across sectors in Austria over the past five years, remaining buoyant in manufacturing but declining in services and construction. Reform backlogs in services hinder competition and reduce other sectors’ prospects of benefiting from cost-efficient intermediate inputs and the diffusion of new technologies.

    The recovery is gaining momentum

    A tax reform, which came into effect at the start of 2016, boosted disposable household income and confidence. Investment growth resumed in 2015 but the investment rate remains considerably below historical average. Despite weak economic growth since 2011 and rising unemployment, inflation has been persistently higher than in other euro area countries. Falling labour productivity in services has raised intermediate costs which may have weakened international competitiveness and contributed to subdued export performance. Structural changes in regional value chains, in particular the relocation of supply chains from Austria to central and eastern European countries, may also partly explain losses in export market shares.

    Export performance and inflation

    Export performance is measured as actual growth in exports relative to the growth of the country’s export markets.

    HCPI.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and Statistics Austria.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367632

    Supply-side reforms should supplement recent demand-side boosts

    The fiscal stance will be slightly expansionary in 2016 owing to expenditures for migrants and a decline in net revenues induced by the tax reform. The winding-down of failed banks is still not completed, but announced bail-in of senior creditors would be an important step towards containing expectations of implicit guarantees. The projection assumes that no additional capital transfers or subsidies to troubled banks will be necessary. Growth could be boosted further and become more inclusive by promoting a more gender-equal society with a tax-and-benefit system that encourages a more balanced distribution of work, the provision of more full-day schools and care centres, and more family-friendly workplaces and working-time models.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369211

    Stringent regulations in the service sector hamper labour productivity and partly explain the relatively high level of inflation. Tackling rigidities in the services sector would improve productivity and provide better jobs in the sector. It may also help to preserve and extend employment in the tradable sector as participation in global and regional production chains increasingly depends on the provision of high-quality services. The integration of refugees into the labour market may temporarily weigh on average productivity but is of critical importance for the preservation of social cohesion, Austria's growth potential and its fiscal position.

    Growth will be led by domestic demand

    GDP growth is projected to increase gradually driven by a pick-up in private consumption and investment. The current account surplus will continue to be supported by buoyant tourism. Some risks surround the projection. Overall export performance may be stronger than projected if lost market shares are regained or weaker if the slide in market shares continues amid subdued competitiveness and restructuring of regional value chains. The restructuring of the banking sector is ongoing which may continue to affect public finances. Associated uncertainties could weigh on confidence and hold back investment more than projected. On the upside, the tax reform could boost private consumption more if saving rates pick up less than expected. Second-round effects of the reform on employment and investment may also be stronger than anticipated. The projected rebound of investment could be hampered by weaker-than-expected growth in the euro area and emerging markets or substantial increases in oil prices.

    Belgium

    Economic growth will slow down in 2016 as fiscal consolidation and wage moderation curb private consumption. In addition, the terrorist attacks in Brussels and Paris in winter have reduced activity, for example in the tourism and restaurant sectors. Activity will gradually accelerate and become more broad-based as firms’ profit margins improve and better financial conditions boost investment. A reform that shifted taxes from earned income to other bases will reduce labour costs and so raise employment. Exports will strengthen as growth picks up in Europe. Inflation will continue to increase, following the rise of indirect taxes in 2016 and as economic slack shrinks.

    The commitment to reach a balanced budget in structural terms by 2018 is welcome given the high public debt. However, the automatic stabilisers should be allowed to operate. Fiscal savings can be reached by improving spending efficiency. Better integration of migrants in the labour market and further strengthening the activation of seniors would make growth more inclusive and sustainable.

    The decline in labour productivity growth has been more pronounced than in other OECD countries. Promoting ICT industries, improving regulation in network industries and reducing barriers to entrepreneurship could strengthen productivity growth.

    The economic recovery remains modest

    Economic growth is becoming more broad-based. Stronger growth in main trading partners, in particular the United States and Europe, are supporting exports. High capacity utilisation rates and the decline of unit labour costs for the second consecutive year are feeding a slow rise of private investment, but a large one-off investment in the pharmaceuticals in 2015 has not been replaced. Low oil prices have boosted household spending, but the pace of consumption growth is slowing as the suspension of the automatic indexation of wages and social benefits and restrictions on collective wage bargaining bear down on real incomes. The terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels have driven down private consumption growth during the first half of 2016. Inflation, the highest in the euro area, is trending up, mainly due to the increases of indirect taxes, in particular on electricity.

    Labour market and inflation

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367640

    Gradual fiscal tightening will resume after a pause in 2016

    The fiscal deficit is the lowest since the financial crisis. Gradual consolidation is appropriate, as public debt exceeds GDP. However, the remaining slack in the economy requires letting the automatic stabilisers operate fully if growth disappoints. Public investment, in particular in transport infrastructure where investment has been comparatively low for decades, should be enhanced to boost competitiveness and productivity.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369222

    The 2015-2019 pro-growth policy of increasing taxation on capital gains, excise duties and value added taxes is welcome. Lower social security contributions for employers, and corporate tax deduction for productive investment in SMEs and for high tech investment, are expected to strengthen labour market performance and productivity growth. Higher tax relief for low wage workers can, by increasing take-home pay, enhance inclusiveness. However, more is needed to ensure equal educational and labour market opportunities, especially for migrants and the low-skilled, notably by reducing the concentration of disadvantaged students in particular schools, delaying tracking in secondary education, and expanding training offers and diversity plans in firms.

    Economic growth will progressively strengthen but external risks remain

    Exports will pick up as activity in the euro area strengthens. The inflation gap with trading partners is expected to remain positive but to narrow as euro area inflation gets closer to the target set by the European Central Bank. Favourable financing conditions will boost private investment. Wage growth is projected to pick up in the second half of 2016 as the indexation mechanism is restored, supporting private consumption. The recovery will lower unemployment but labour market slack will remain.

    Prolonged weaker-than-projected growth in main trading partners would reduce growth. A Brexit scenario combined with lower economic growth in the United Kingdom would in particular undermine exports as the United Kingdom accounts for almost 9% of total exports. Another risk is lower growth in emerging markets, including China: even though the markets represent only a small portion of exports, the effect could be substantial through global value chains. Increased financial volatility in emerging markets and uncertainty regarding the oil price could also lower business confidence and investment. By contrast, domestic demand could be stronger if the tax shift policy has a stronger-than-expected impact on labour and capital demand.

    Brazil

    The deep recession is set to continue in 2016 and in 2017 against the backdrop of high political uncertainty and ongoing corruption revelations that are undermining consumer and business confidence, leading to a continuous contraction in domestic demand. As the economy shrinks, unemployment is set to rise further. Inflation will gradually return into the target range as the effects of administrative price increases and past currency depreciation wear off and economic slack widens.

    Deep political divisions have reduced the chances for any noticeable momentum on policy reforms in the near term and gross government debt is continuing to rise. Improvements in confidence will depend on the authorities’ ability to implement a significant fiscal adjustment, including steps to ensure the sustainability of the pension system, and a new wave of structural reforms. While remaining restrictive, monetary policy will loosen slightly as inflation declines.

    Raising productivity will depend on reforms to boost competition, lower trade barriers and administrative burdens and simplify indirect taxes. Given that demographics will provide much less support than they have in the past, stronger productivity will be key for solid economic growth in the medium term.

    Political uncertainty is high and confidence low

    The economy is in a severe recession. Over the past 12 months, almost 2 million formal jobs have been lost and the currency has depreciated by almost 20%, despite a slight appreciation in recent months. Corporate bankruptcies and debt have risen. The low investor and consumer confidence have fallen further as political uncertainty has deepened. A presidential impeachment procedure is ongoing and an interim government has been formed, but political uncertainty and instability are likely to remain.

    Confidence and bankrupcy

    Fundação Getúlio Vargas; Confederação Nacional de Indústria; Serasa/Experian; and CEMEC-IBMEC.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367654

    Fiscal results have deteriorated further and inflation remains high

    The fiscal deficit has risen to above 10% of GDP and the primary deficit exceeds 2% of GDP, even though Brazil requires primary surpluses to keep its public debt on a firmly declining path. Another rating downgrade occurred in December, and no major rating agency now considers Brazil’s sovereign debt to be investment grade. This deterioration is due to declining revenues in the face of the recession, and there may be further revenue shortfalls. The plan to unwind significant tax exemptions was not fully implemented, further weakening the fiscal position. Expenditures continue on an upward trend while spending efficiency remains low. Year-on-year inflation is slowly coming down as the recession reduces inflationary pressures and the strong increases in administrative prices in early 2015 are beginning to fall out of the 12-month window. Still, inflation remains well above the ceiling of the target range of 6.5%.

    Macroeconomic indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369473

    Structural reforms should support economic adjustment and inclusive growth

    Structural reforms have a significant potential to boost growth. Reducing the compliance costs and distortions imposed by Brazil’s fragmented system of indirect taxes would provide an almost immediate cost reduction for firms, and could be achieved by consolidating indirect taxes into a single, broad-based value-added tax with full deductibility for inputs and a zero-rating for exports. In addition, reducing barriers to international trade would reduce the costs of imported inputs and strengthen incentives to enhance productivity. Improvements in infrastructure could also reduce transport costs, particularly for exporters. Stronger trade integration would benefit low-income earners in particular, as an expansion of the export sector would have a larger impact on the demand for low-skilled labour. Further improvements in educational attainment would not only raise productivity, but also allow more low-income households to join Brazil’s growing middle class.

    Fiscal policy and inflation

    The inflation target is met whenever the accumulated inflation during the period January-December of each year falls within the tolerance band.

    Central Bank of Brazil; and IBGE.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367663

    The economy will remain in recession over the projection period, but political upside risks exist

    In the baseline scenario, the political situation will remain highly uncertain throughout the projection period and confidence levels will remain subdued. In this scenario, growth will be negative in both 2016 and 2017 as domestic demand fails to show any significant signs of recovery. Only export growth remains solid, buoyed by a more competitive exchange rate and new export opportunities gradually being seized by businesses. Imports are projected to decline as domestic demand shrinks. As a result, the current account deficit narrows. Unemployment is projected to rise further. Inflation will continue to decline due to weak activity, and the monetary authorities will be in a position to lower the monetary policy rate. While remaining above the 4.5% inflation target, inflation is projected to return into the tolerance band during 2017, whose ceiling will then be at 6%.

    As the political panorama has a major impact on economic performance, it presents both upside and downside risks for the projections. If uncertainty about future policies is resolved more rapidly than assumed and a consensus for reforms is achieved, confidence could improve rapidly and growth could even be positive in 2017. At the same time, the deep political divisions could also lead to further instability well into 2018, which would make it very difficult to pursue the economic policies needed to sustain growth.

    Volatility on international capital markets could return in the context of monetary policy normalisation in the United States, but Brazil’s high foreign currency reserves of USD 351 billion (20% of GDP) provide a strong cushion. Additional downside risks could come from the corporate sector, where the effects of the ongoing recession are becoming increasingly visible. Bankruptcy filings are increasing across all company sizes and corporate defaults may rise going forward. Among publicly traded companies, net financial debt rose by 24% during 2015, at the same time as earnings declined by 29%, without counting the three large companies with public participation (Petrobras, Vale, Electrobras). Further currency depreciation could help exporters, but it could also imply difficulties for corporate borrowers, even if almost half of the corporate debt in foreign currency is hedged or backed by export revenues. A further slowdown of growth in China, the export destination for many of Brazil’s commodity exports, could also reduce growth in Brazil.

    Canada

    Economic growth is projected to strengthen in 2016 and reach 2.2% in 2017. As the contraction in the resource sector slows, activity in the rest of the economy is projected to gain traction. Non-energy exports should continue to benefit from the earlier depreciation and strengthening export market growth. Consumer price inflation is projected to rise to around 2% as the effect of falling gasoline prices fades and excess capacity is gradually eliminated.

    The moderately expansionary policy stance in the 2016 federal budget will help the economy return to full employment. In the medium term however, in light of provinces’ unfavourable debt dynamics, the government should adopt ambitious medium-term debt and budget balance objectives to ensure that general government debt remains sustainable. Gradual increases in policy interest rates are assumed from late 2016 to stabilise inflation at around 2%. Macro-prudential measures should be tightened further and targeted regionally to reduce financial-stability risks from high household debt and house prices.

    Reducing barriers to foreign direct investment in telecommunications and broadcasting and air transportation would boost productivity and reduce quality-adjusted prices. Such measures would also disproportionately benefit lower- and middle-income households. Boosting inter-provincial competition by liberalising electricity generation and distribution and reducing barriers to internal trade would have similar effects. Replacing the tax preference for small companies by targeted measures for small businesses having difficulty obtaining finance would also boost productivity.

    The economy is recovering

    Looking through quarterly volatility, real GDP is expanding at an annual rate of around 2%. Growth in non-commodity export-related industries has picked up to still higher rates, aided by the earlier fall in the Canadian dollar and the recovery in export markets, but industries most affected by commodity prices remain depressed. Business investment in the oil and gas sector continues to fall sharply – it is likely to be about 60% below its 2014 level in 2016 - but should be a smaller drag on growth thereafter. Other business investment is also weak but should pick up as capacity utilisation in many non-commodity exporting sectors is already high and credit conditions are easing. Growth in private consumption has been subdued, reflecting adjustment to the terms of trade losses since mid-2014 (amounting to about 3% of national income), but should get a boost from the new Canada Child Benefit. At the national level, housing starts are running at the higher end of demographic requirements and housing investment is robust, especially in British Columbia and Ontario, although it is declining in oil-producing provinces. The recent fires in Alberta have shut down some oil-sands production, depressing economic growth in the second quarter of 2016, but activity is likely to bounce back in the third quarter as production resumes.

    Exports and Investment

    Three-month moving average of real output.

    For more details on the composition of the industries and their weight on GDP, see note in Chart 9 of Bank of Canada (2016).

    Includes oil and gas. Also includes some engineering structures investment that may relate to other sectors.

    Bank of Canada (2016), Monetary Policy Report, April, Chart 9; Statistics Canada, Tables 379-0031 and 380-0068; OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367670

    Despite steady employment growth, the unemployment rate has remained slightly over 7% since late 2014. High involuntary part-time employment and long-term unemployment, as well as weak wage pressures, point to continued labour market slack. Consumer price inflation has fallen to the lower end of the Bank of Canada’s 1-3% target range despite the exchange rate depreciation, but this reflects falling gasoline prices — excluding these, inflation is near 2%.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369127

    Macroeconomic policies are expansionary

    Fiscal stimulus in the recent budget could boost GDP growth by around 0.5% in both 2016 and 2017. The general government deficit is projected to rise by 0.5% of GDP over 2015-17, to 2.2% of GDP. This increase mainly reflects 2016 federal budget measures to boost demand, notably infrastructure spending, which is a government priority. The new policy package also includes measures to redistribute income towards low- and middle-income families. The most important of these is the replacement of existing programmes to help families with children, some of which are not means tested, by the means-tested Canada Child Benefit. There is also a substantial increase in funding to improve conditions for Aboriginal peoples.

    Labour market and inflation

    Twelve-month moving average.

    Percentage of firms reporting more intense labour shortages minus the percentage reporting less intense shortages.

    Statistics Canada, Tables 282-001, 282-0047 and 326-0020; Bank of Canada (2016), Business Outlook Survey - Results of the Spring 2016 Survey, April.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367683

    The central bank held its policy rate unchanged at 0.5% at its April meeting, despite upward pressure on the dollar. Based on the Bank’s projection that economic slack will be taken up by the second half of 2017, the projection assumes that monetary stimulus will be gradually withdrawn starting in late 2016. Very low borrowing rates have encouraged household credit growth and underpinned rapidly rising housing prices, particularly in Vancouver and Toronto, which together are a third of the Canadian housing market. In relation to household incomes, both house prices and household debt are high. Macro‑prudential measures have been strengthened recently but should be tightened further and targeted regionally.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369131

    A number of policies could raise productivity and reduce income inequality. In telecoms and broadcasting and air transportation, easing restrictive foreign ownership rules would sharpen competitive pressures, raise productivity and reduce prices for consumers. In the electricity sector, developing more east-west connections where economic and allowing competition in generation and retail distribution would also lower prices. In inter-provincial trade, to reduce non-tariff barriers, which raise costs and prices, coverage of the Agreement on Internal Trade should be broadened and provincial authorities should reconcile regulatory differences, in some cases by recognising each other’s regulations.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369148

    Growth in non-energy exports and investment should lead the recovery

    Economic growth is projected to strengthen in 2016 and reach 2.2% in 2017. The drag from falling investment and employment in the resource sector should soon peak and then gradually fade away. Non-energy exports should lead the recovery as they continue to benefit from the lower Canadian dollar and strengthening export market growth. Business investment outside the resource sector should rise with a lag as sectoral capacity constraints become binding. Growth in housing investment, on the other hand, should weaken, as further supply comes onto the market and the boost from past interest rate cuts fades. With moderate growth in household incomes, private consumption should continue to grow steadily. The unemployment rate is projected to edge down to 6¾ per cent by late 2017, and, with gasoline prices and the exchange rate stable and excess capacity eliminated, the inflation rate could rise to around 2%, the midpoint of the Bank of Canada’s target range.

    External indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369150

    The greatest risk surrounding these projections is global oil prices. If they were to be higher than assumed, this would limit cuts in energy-sector investment and employment, while further falls in prices would accentuate these cuts. Developments in emerging market economies, notably China, will have an important bearing on commodity prices and export demand. The main domestic downside risk is a disorderly housing market correction, particularly in the high-price Toronto and Vancouver markets. This would damp residential investment and private consumption, and could threaten financial stability. In addition, the rotation of economic activity from commodity-producing sectors to other sectors could be more protracted than expected. The main upside risk is that the US economic expansion could be stronger than projected, lifting demand for Canadian exports.

    Chile

    Economic growth is projected to moderate further in 2016, reflecting weak commodity prices, tighter financial conditions and fragile consumer and business confidence. Activity will improve in 2017 as confidence starts to rebound and the global economy strenghtens, underpinning a gradual recovery in investment and private consumption. Once the effects of the past currency depreciation have worn off, inflation will return to within the central bank’s tolerance range.

    The central bank raised its main policy interest rate to 3.5% in 2015 to contain inflation. As long as inflation expectations remain well-anchored, monetary policy should remain accommodative to support economic activity, as fiscal policy is becoming less expansionary in response to lower expected medium-term copper prices.

    Measures to boost productivity were introduced in the context of 2016 as the Year of Productivity in Chile, and a new bill with key measures has been sent to Congress. Actions are intended to improve access to financing, increase exports of services, and simplify regulatory procedures to strengthen entrepreneurship and investment. Implementation of such initiatives can both raise growth and ensure that more Chileans can benefit from higher incomes.

    Growth is moderate due to lower commodity prices

    Economic growth has continued to moderate due to low copper prices and weak external demand, which has cut private investment, especially in mining. More restrictive lending conditions and lower business confidence have also held back investment. Private consumption growth has also declined significantly, reflecting weaker real income growth and a deterioration of consumer confidence. As growth slows, the labour market has weakened and unemployment is drifting up.

    Inflation and productivity

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367697

    Monetary policy is supportive although fiscal policy is becoming less expansionary

    Inflation remains above the central bank’s tolerance range of 2% to 4% due to the partial pass-through of currency depreciation. To make inflation converge to the target, the central bank has appropriately raised its interest rate by 50 basis points, to 3.5%, in the last quarter of 2015, stating that further increases would be required, but at a slow pace. However, since inflation is already showing signs of decline and inflation expectations are well anchored, monetary policy should remain supportive given that economic slack is expected to rise in the next several months. Furthermore, fiscal consolidation measures, concentrated mostly on current expenditures and consistent with the fiscal rule, were recently announced in response to lower expected medium-term copper prices. As a result, there will be little support from this source.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369230

    Measures such as the recently announced first Strategic Programme to increase mining productivity should help to develop providers, technologies, and services for mining that could be used in other sectors and exported to foreign markets, allowing for larger inclusion of domestic producers in global value chains. Initiatives to diversify exports and encourage non-mining investment are also welcome to broaden the base of the economy and support inclusive growth. A credit line to enhance small-company financing, allowing insurance and pension funds to invest in infrastructure, and simplifying procedures for service exporters should all facilitate entrepreneurship and investment. However, measures to strengthen inclusivity by bridging skills mismatches in the labour market and to foster female and youth participation to reduce inequalities are still needed to expand opportunities for everyone to enjoy the benefits of greater prosperity.

    Growth will gradually recover in an uncertain external environment

    Growth in 2016 will moderate as investment and external demand stay weak, and fiscal policy moves from an expansionary to a neutral stance. As growth weakens, the unemployment rate is projected to increase in 2016 and 2017. Activity will pick up in 2017 driven mainly by an improving export performance reflecting competitiveness gains and stronger external demand, which will spur investment and private consumption.

    The main risks to growth relate to the growth of Chile’s trading partners and the evolution of commodity prices. Weaker-than-projected demand from China and Latin America, or volatile global financial conditions, would reduce external demand. Growth could also be weakened if business confidence does not revive. On the upside, a recovery of the price of copper would boost confidence and investment, and increase government revenues. New measures to boost competition and productivity could improve the business climate more than assumed. Risks for inflation remain closely tied to the evolution of the exchange rate and oil prices.

    China

    Economic growth is set to edge down further, from 6.5% in 2016 to 6.2% by 2017. Large-scale infrastructure spending will only partly make up for slowing business investment as overcapacity is being worked off in several industries. Real estate investment is bottoming out, but housing inventories remain sizeable. Consumption is projected to stay buoyant. The reduction in excess capacity will ease the downward pressure on producer prices, but consumer price inflation will remain low.

    Monetary policy is assumed to ease to reduce financing costs and to provide adequate liquidity. Market forces should be allowed to drive the pricing of credit risk by removing implicit guarantees and ending bailouts. Corporations need to deleverage as slowing growth heightens credit risks. Fiscal policy is being eased significantly, potentially crowding out of private investment and building up imbalances. Spending should be targeted at areas that promote long-term inclusive growth, such as ensuring equal access to public services and extending the social safety net.

    Productivity gains are becoming the main engine of improvements in living standards as capital-deepening-led growth has run its course. This calls for fostering innovation and entrepreneurship. Lower barriers to entry have spurred entrepreneurial activity, but the exit mechanism for unviable firms should also be streamlined. Policy emphasis is shifting towards supply-side reforms that seek to ensure sustainable development. Reallocation of labour from agriculture to industry and services has been a major driver of inclusive productivity growth and is likely to continue in the future.

    Supply-side reforms to curb overcapacity are gathering momentum

    Growth continues to decline as adjustment in manufacturing sectors plagued by excess capacity gathers momentum. Capacity cuts started in the coal and steel sectors, with cancelling or delaying new construction as well as closing inefficient and heavily-polluting firms. Consequently, manufacturing investment remains sluggish by historical standards. Real estate investment is bottoming out, although trends in upper and lower-tier cities are increasingly diverging with sharply rising demand and prices in the former, prompting new home purchase restrictions. The implementation of programmed infrastructure projects is accelerating.

    Industrial output and Investment

    Fixed asset investment and manufacturing investment refer to nominal values and do not include investment by rural households.

    CEIC.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367704

    Consumption has remained robust, supported by stable employment prospects and steadily rising incomes, in particular in rural areas, showing that growth is becoming more inclusive. Some services, such as tourism and cultural services as well as e-commerce, are thriving. Weak business investment demand weighs on imports and so do rising costs on exports. Producer price declines have moderated as excess capacity is being removed and infrastructure and real estate investment strengthened.

    Macroeconomic indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369489

    Policy easing and structural reforms support growth

    Monetary policy has remained accommodative with a combination of conventional and non-conventional easing measures to provide liquidity, resulting in strong lending growth. Financing costs have come down slightly, but are still high in real terms as producer prices keep falling. Continued easing will reduce costs further and provide sufficient liquidity amid capital outflows. Corporate profitability is recovering after a sharp fall in 2015, against the backdrop of more moderate producer price deflation. Leverage, especially in the state-owned sector, remains high. Debt-equity swaps may provide only temporary relief, and may also delay necessary adjustment, including the exit of unviable firms. Loans with past due payment have risen sharply, foreshadowing a surge in bad debt. Recent defaults are expected to instil greater market discipline and better credit risk pricing. Collateralisation of land operation rights will allow farmers to buy housing in small cities, where inventories are high, though for such cities to become attractive, they need to provide better public services and job opportunities.

    Capacity utilisation and state-owned enterprise

    Leverage is defined as the liabilities-to-equity ratio. Overall as well as state-owned refer to industrial enterprises.

    CEIC.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367713

    Exchange rate transparency has improved. The People’s Bank of China started to publish a trade-weighted currency index at the end of 2015, and disclosed its weights. Notwithstanding the delay of further US interest rate hikes, capital outflows continued, leading to a contraction of foreign exchange reserves through February 2016 and putting pressure on the exchange rate. Expected renminbi depreciation has led the corporate sector to reduce its foreign liabilities and boost its foreign assets. Individuals will also likely diversify their asset holdings as the capital account opens up further. Continued expectations of depreciation could trigger additional outflows, exacerbating the pressure on the exchange rate.

    Fiscal policy is set to loosen further with a 3% of GDP deficit target for 2016, up from a deficit of 2.4% in 2015. In terms of a broader and internationally more comparable definition of the budget, adding up all four budget accounts, this implies a deficit of 1.3% of GDP in 2015 and 1.8% in 2016. Additional large-scale quasi-fiscal spending through policy banks, which will partly finance the 2016-18 grandiose infrastructure package, will further ensure that the growth target is met. Local government investment vehicles, which have fuelled the urbanisation boom but also the accumulation of illicit sub-national government debt, will have fast-track access to the enterprise bond market and to subsidised loans, which may lead to another potential round of bailouts. Conversion of the business tax into a value-added tax in the remaining service industries will support services growth and more specialisation in general through outsourcing, thereby enhancing overall efficiency.

    Rebalancing might stall

    The large ongoing stimulus measures will ensure that growth remains in the range of 6.5-7% in 2016. The structure of investment is tilted towards infrastructure and real estate, while excess capacity will continue to weigh on business capital spending. State-owned enterprise reform will focus on mergers and acquisitions as well as streamlining business operations, leaving exit as a last option. Investment is increasingly financed by public funds, crowding out the private sector and potentially leading to further misallocation of capital. Slow corporate profit growth and high leverage will constrain household income growth, holding back consumption growth. Gradual adjustment in the industrial sector is expected to lead to moderate producer price reflation. While the planned adjustment in the steel and coal sectors will not have a major labour market impact, creating enough jobs for new graduates that meet their expectations appears more of a challenge.

    Greater-than-expected stimulus would result in stronger growth in the short term, though it would increase vulnerability over longer horizons. By the same token, faster-than-planned adjustment in the industrial sector would drag growth down, although that would improve the economy's resilience. Supply-side policies, including deleveraging and working off excess capacity, are crucial to avoid a sharp slowdown. Delayed adjustment continues to exert downward pressure on prices, which in turn hinders profit recovery and potentially increases future non-performing loans. In addition, the re-leveraging of local government investment vehicles could augment future government debt due to the assumed implicit guarantees and bailout. A further rebound in commodity prices could ease downward price pressure in upstream industries and help profit recovery in some industries.

    Colombia

    Economic growth will continue to moderate in 2016, reflecting weak external conditions, low commodity prices and a slowdown in internal demand, but it will strengthen to 3% in 2017, as external demand recovers and the government’s infrastructure agenda is implemented. The current account deficit remains high and inflation is accelerating due to exchange rate depreciation and rising food prices resulting from El Niño . As the effects of these shocks dissipate, inflation will gradually come down in 2017.

    Monetary policy has appropriately become less accommodative to anchor inflation expectations. Credit growth has weakened but inflation expectations remain high. The announced cut in public spending is appropriate to contain the headline fiscal deficit, but a comprehensive tax reform is required to increase progressivity, boost revenues and reduce the large inequalities in incomes.

    Productivity growth has declined in recent years. Strengthening competitiveness through simplified customs procedures, infrastructure investment and streamlined regulation are needed to improve productivity in the medium term. The plans to broaden access to quality education will also contribute to productive transformation and allow the fruits of growth to be shared more equitably, increasing social cohesion. Reaching an agreement on the peace talks is crucial to boost confidence and investment.

    Adjustment to the terms-of-trade shock continues

    The value of exports of crude oil and coal, which represent two-thirds of total exports, has collapsed since 2013. As a result, the exchange rate has depreciated sharply and the current account and fiscal deficit have widened, despite recent spending cuts introduced by the government. The intensification of El Niño is hurting the agricultural sector and power generation, weakening consumer confidence, private consumption and employment growth. Inflation has accelerated to nearly 8% since mid-2015 due to the exchange rate depreciation and pressures on food and energy prices created by El Niño.

    External trade and inflation

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; Central Bank of Colombia.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367723

    Macroeconomic policies are appropriate, but structural reforms are required to boost productivity

    The central bank has increased interest rates by 250 basis points since September 2015. With real interest rates in negative territory, monetary policy remains appropriately accommodative, but is assumed to cautiously move to a more neutral stance to bring inflation expectations back into line with the target of the central bank. Financial soundness indicators have been strong and the exposure of the financial system to the oil sector is very low. Due to the fall of oil revenues, the government announced a reduction of public expenditure to comply with the fiscal rule in 2016. The cuts are appropriately well‑targeted to smooth the social impact. However, in the medium term, a comprehensive tax reform is needed to raise more revenue, given the need to accommodate public finances to the seemingly permanently lower commodity prices, and make growth more inclusive.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369536

    Structural reforms that improve public infrastructure, raise productivity and make growth more inclusive are essential for strong and sustainable development. Barriers to trade and competition, which prevent entry of new innovative and dynamic firms and prevent allocation of labour and capital resources towards high-productivity firms and sectors, should be reduced. Broadening access to quality education and training is also essential for boosting labour productivity and reduce income inequality. Finally, policies to address labour market duality, create quality jobs, and reduce gender gaps and informality can increase growth by enhancing domestic demand, while reducing income inequality.

    Growth is projected to pick up only gradually

    Growth in 2016 will continue to be weakened by falling real incomes, increasing interest rates, and low demand. The envisaged fiscal consolidation, a decrease in private investment due to low commodity prices, and deteriorated business confidence will add to the weak growth outlook. However, activity is projected to improve in 2017 supported by the implementation of the government’s infrastructure agenda, the re-opening of Cartagena Refinery and a pick-up of exports, which will benefit from the depreciation of the exchange rate and stronger external demand. The persistence of El Niño and the activation of an indexing mechanism will continue to put pressure on prices during 2016, but as these effects dissipate, inflation will gradually come down in 2017.

    The still significant current account deficit, large near-term external financing needs and potential capital inflow reversals resulting from volatile global financial conditions bear on the outlook. A deterioration of growth prospects of China or regional trading partners’ could also generate negative financial and real spill-overs. Declines in oil prices could also fuel additional currency depreciation and inflation. On the upside, bringing the peace process to fruition could improve business confidence and capital inflows, reinforcing the recovery that will follow the necessary adjustment process.

    Costa Rica

    After weak growth last year, activity is set to accelerate in 2016-17. Domestic demand is projected to be the main driver, but exports will also recover as world markets regain momentum. The unemployment rate is likely to remain above 9%. After falling temporarily into negative territory at the end of 2015, inflation will slowly return to the central bank’s target as the economy strengthens.

    Public debt has continued to increase and reached 42.4% of GDP in 2015. With credit rating agencies having a negative outlook and bond investors requiring high risk spreads, measures to restore fiscal sustainability have become urgent. The reforms proposed by the government, if approved and implemented, would be just enough to stabilise the debt-to-GDP ratio at the current level. But additional measures, such as further tax reform and reforming public employment, will be needed to ensure more robust debt sustainability.

    Disappointing labour productivity growth calls for measures to promote innovation, competition and transport infrastructure. Such reforms need to go together with making Costa Rica a more inclusive society by improving the quality of education and reducing gender inequalities.

    Activity is rising

    Real GDP rose by 2.9% in 2015. Domestic demand was boosted by the improved terms of trade, from lower import commodity prices, and higher investment, which more than offset the withdrawal of a large electronics company and adverse weather conditions related to El Niño. Household consumption recovered significantly, supported by the favourable terms of trade, low interest rates and price stability. Owing to falling oil prices and the stability of the exchange rate, consumer prices fell in the second half of 2015.

    Budget balance and labour productivity

    OECD refers to the 17 upper half countries based on GDP per capita; GDP is expressed in 2011 PPP.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and OECD calculations based on the Conference Board Total Economy Database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367739

    Reforms are required to tackle the fiscal challenge and boost productivity

    Increased budget deficits have resulted in rising public debt, which almost doubled in the period 2008-2015, reaching 42.4% of GDP. The authorities have proposed a plan to start gradual fiscal adjustment this year, which is under discussion in the parliament. The package of tax reform and stricter expenditure control, if legislated and implemented, would cut the deficit by about 2% of GDP during 2016-17. However, additional fiscal adjustment of 1% of GDP will be needed to put debt on a firm downward path. Steps towards this include the recent legislative proposals to reform public employment conditions, thus preventing excessive automatic increases in current outlays, and further tax reform to increase revenues and reduce Costa Rica’s high inequality.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369558

    Structural reforms are needed to boost productivity and to make the society more inclusive. Enhancing productivity requires a comprehensive strategy to strengthen institutions, enhance competition, promote innovation and access to finance, and improve transport infrastructure. Raising the quality of education and work prospects for women would decrease inequality by expanding opportunities and sharing prosperity more widely.

    Strong GDP growth will be led by domestic demand, but downside risks loom

    Growth is projected to continue to accelerate, supported by domestic demand and an improving export performance; however, it will not reach a pace sufficient to reduce unemployment from its high level. Factors supporting strong growth include the continued US recovery, domestic monetary stimulus and continued real credit expansion. Inflation will remain weak in 2016, slowly returning towards the new central bank target range of 2‑4% as the economy strengthens.

    As Costa Rica is a small open economy, external developments are critical. Costa Rica is an energy importer, so global energy prices are important for growth and incomes. Global market volatility, deeper-than-expected slowdowns in advanced and emerging market economies and currency depreciation, could create problems for the stability of the banking system given its high credit dollarisation. On the domestic front, persistently large fiscal deficits and rising public debt make the economy vulnerable to sudden changes in financial market conditions. In addition, large government gross financing requirements could push up domestic interest rates, weighing on private investment and consumption, and limiting the transmission of the monetary stimulus to lending rates.

    Czech Republic

    GDP growth increased strongly in 2015, partly due to EU-financed public investment. Financial conditions and income growth will continue to support domestic demand, but falling public investment is weighing on growth in 2016. Although gains in market share are likely to be smaller than in recent years, stronger demand from European countries will support export growth. Headline inflation remains low, but robust wage growth and fading effects of food and energy price falls will push inflation to the 2% target by end‑2017.

    The exchange rate floor prevented appreciation of the currency and thereby helped to contain deflationary pressures. As these pressures are waning, the central bank has rightly confirmed that the floor is temporary. Public investment has fallen sharply with the transition to the new EU programming period, and will be offset only partly by spending elsewhere.

    Income convergence stalled in the aftermath of the crisis. Structural policies are needed to underpin faster growth on a sustainable and inclusive basis. Policies should focus on generating domestic innovation and creating conditions for successful SMEs to flourish. Expanding childcare availability would increase labour market participation and reduce gender-related wage gaps, thereby reducing labour market tightness and improving inclusiveness.

    Growth has slowed after an exceptional year

    In 2015, a push to use expiring EU funds contributed to the fastest GDP growth since 2007. Private investment has been supported by growth in profits and credit, but public investment is falling. The buoyant labour market, income growth and accommodative financial conditions have bolstered consumer confidence. The saving rate has declined and consumption growth is robust. Exports accelerated in late 2015 and are benefitting from favourable developments in the important automotive industry. Falling food and energy prices are temporarily holding down inflation, but increasing wages are pushing up costs.

    Consumer confidence and inflation

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and OECD, Main Economic Indicators database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367746

    Monetary and fiscal policies are supportive

    The policy rate remains near zero and borrowing rates have eased further. The central bank announced that it expects to maintain the exchange rate floor until mid-2017. It has intervened to maintain the floor in most months since July 2015. It will be appropriate to exit the floor as the effects of food and energy price falls pass and inflation rises. There is room for fiscal policy to support activity if the exchange rate appreciates too sharply.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369244

    Public investment will subtract from GDP growth with the transition to the new EU programming period, although fiscal policy is projected to be expansionary in 2016 due to other spending. More domestically-funded investment could reduce infrastructure gaps or improve energy efficiency and also smooth the cycle. The fiscal responsibility package – including a fiscal council and a debt brake – should be passed to buttress medium-term fiscal sustainability.

    Structural policies are needed to boost productivity and accelerate income convergence

    The government is gradually raising the retirement age and expanding childcare availability, to foster greater participation of older people and women in the labour market. Labour participation rates are rising but further steps are needed to offset population ageing and prevent labour market tightness from constraining the economy. Increased childcare access could reduce the gender pay gap by facilitating mothers’ return to work.

    Faster productivity growth would speed up income convergence. Reforms are needed to allow successful firms to expand and unproductive firms to exit more easily. These include increasing competition in product markets and reducing the cost of bankruptcy proceedings. Spurring domestic innovation would boost productivity. Increasing skills and reducing barriers to worker mobility could reduce mismatches and raise productivity and wages alike.

    Private domestic demand will continue to drive growth

    Household consumption will continue to drive GDP growth, supported by growth in employment and wages. The unemployment rate is expected to fall below its pre-crisis level. Profit and credit growth will support private fixed investment. Housing starts data suggest housing construction may soften the effect of falling public investment on construction activity. Stronger demand from trading partners, including in Europe, will boost exports. Domestic costs will maintain inflationary pressures. Headline inflation is projected to remain subdued in 2016 but should reach 2% by end-2017.

    External developments pose both upside and downside risks, given the economy’s integration in global value chains. Reduction in the degree of European integration, disappointing growth in Europe or the transmission of slower growth in big emerging economies would hit exports and investment. On the upside, a faster pick-up in wage growth or a lower savings rate would result in stronger consumption growth. Faster take-up of EU funds would boost public investment.

    Denmark

    Economic growth is projected to rise to nearly 2% in 2017, driven mainly by domestic demand. Private consumption will be supported by growth in real incomes, related to higher employment and real wage gains, as well as by increasing property prices. Exports are projected to rebound somewhat after a very weak 2015.

    Spare capacity in the economy is diminishing, and accordingly fiscal policy should gradually move towards a more neutral stance. Investment activity should benefit from the accommodative monetary policy stance, which is expected to remain through the peg to the euro. As real estate prices continue to rise, notably in the Copenhagen area, macro-prudential measures have been rightly stepped up in order to prevent the build-up of imbalances.

    Subdued productivity growth continues to be a major long-term challenge. More reforms are crucial, particularly in areas such as domestic services and innovation. A number of reforms have been launched, but more can be done, for instance boosting competition in retailing and pharmacies; such reforms would reduce prices, favouring the less well-off particularly.

    The economy is growing – but only slowly

    Exports have been weak, in part because of the slowdown in Europe and Asia. On the other hand, private consumption continues to underpin growth as households benefit from private sector job creation and real wage gains. Consumer sentiment is supported by loose monetary conditions, low inflation and rising house prices. Business investment is expanding only slowly, reflecting in part weak exports. Housing investment has not yet reacted to higher property prices, partly reflecting the lack of building land in metropolitan areas, where prices have increased most. Consumer price inflation hovers around zero, pulled down by low energy prices, while core inflation has come down to less than 1%.

    Consumption and house prices

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and Statistics Denmark.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367759

    Economic policy remains accommodative

    The central bank’s policy rate is -0.65% and has been negative since the fall of 2014, to contain surges in demand for the krone. The peg to the euro means that the policy rate is likely to remain negative and the interest rates are assumed to be low over the projection period. This may increase the risk of unsustainable increases in property prices. Before this risk materialises, fiscal and macro-prudential policies need to be stepped up to avoid a repeat of past boom and bust episodes. Fiscal policy has been accommodative overall. Low oil prices and declining oil production in the North Sea has weighed on government revenues, and are expected to continue to do so. Fiscal policy is expected to tighten only gradually, partly through a reduction in investment. However, this may be insufficient to contain emerging imbalances in the economy, particularly, given the already small degree of labour market slack. Further decreasing interest rate tax deductibility and regularly updating property valuations are the preferred forms of fiscal tightening in the medium term and would also establish tax neutrality across different asset classes.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369254

    Growth will remain slow in 2016 before accelerating

    Growth is projected to pick up during 2016 as exports recover, notably due to improvements in the euro area. Private consumption should continue to support growth, underpinned by the strong labour market although high household debt will weigh on household finances. This will support property prices across the country, which should underpin residential investments. Investment should firm on the back of broad-based demand increases, higher capacity utilisation and low interest rates. Inflation is projected to rise gradually, as the spare capacity in the economy declines and commodity prices recover.

    Continued trade weakness linked to a slowdown in emerging markets, in particular China, or disappointing growth in the euro area pose the main downside risks to exports. A potential Brexit could also hamper exports, as the United Kingdom is the fourth largest market for Danish exports. On the domestic side, stronger debt reduction among households would weaken domestic demand in the short term, but would provide room for stronger consumption and investment later on. The very supportive monetary policy stance, low energy prices and rising property prices could boost domestic demand further in the projection period. Likewise, recent labour market reforms could have a larger-than-expected effect on labour supply.

    Estonia

    Economic growth is projected to strengthen gradually, boosted by private consumption. Exports and investment will gain some momentum in 2017 as economic activity strengthens in European trading partners. Shortages of skilled labour will push up wages and raise consumer price inflation somewhat.

    The government’s fiscal stance is slightly expansionary, but public debt is very low. Reducing the structural surplus further would be appropriate to fund increased growth-enhancing spending, including for education and infrastructure. Aligning energy tax rates across different energy sources more closely and raising them according to their CO2 content would help improve energy efficiency, which is lower than in most OECD countries.

    Labour productivity declined in 2015 and is expected to recover only gradually. Improving collaboration in applied research between domestic and foreign institutions, strengthening infrastructure, in particular by expanding access to European transport networks, and shortening corporate insolvency procedures would accelerate productivity growth. Strengthening vocational training would boost the productivity of low-wage workers, thereby making growth more inclusive.

    Economic growth is subdued

    Economic growth has been driven by robust private consumption, supported by strong wage growth, low energy prices, as well as by lower personal income tax and unemployment insurance contributions. Recorded employment has grown strongly, but this partly reflects stepped up requirements for employers to register informal workers. Unemployment has fallen, pushing up wage growth. Exports to Russia have dropped while growth of exports to other major trade partners, notably Finland, has remained modest. Transportation, storage and wholesale trade services have been particularly affected by the drop in trade with Russia. While cheaper oil has reduced import and consumer prices, it has weighed on the production of oil shale and oil shale products. Weak exports have held back business investment despite the favourable funding conditions.

    Business confidence and labour costs

    Export performance is measured as the ratio of actual export volume and the country’s export market.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and OECD Business Tendency and Consumer Opinion Indicators.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367761

    The government has taken steps to address labour shortages

    The decline in the working-age population and shortages of skilled workers keep the labour market tight and wage pressures high. The increase in the minimum wage by 10% in both 2016 and 2017 will reduce in-work poverty and boost wages more generally, thereby encouraging Estonians to remain, rather than emigrate, and easing labour shortages. The reform of disability benefits in 2016 will also increase labour supply by introducing stricter assessments of work capacity and offering more counselling and training. The government also took measures to alleviate skill mismatch, such as extending the apprenticeship programme and strengthening capabilities to forecast the supply of, and demand for, skills.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369263

    To improve the position of poor workers and encourage work, the basic personal income tax allowance will be raised in 2016 and 2017, further income tax reductions will apply to workers earning less than EUR 649 per month and in 2017 health insurance contributions will be reduced. The impact on tax revenues will be partly offset by higher taxes on alcohol, tobacco and fuels. These measures will boost employment, competitiveness and private consumption, especially among low-income households. Government investment is expected to dip as the use of EU structural funds from the 2009‑2013 allocation period has come to an end.

    Investment will strengthen as export markets recover

    GDP growth is projected to pick up as stronger exports encourage business investment. The government’s tax measures and structural reforms will mitigate the effect of wage growth on Estonia’s competitiveness. The unemployment rate will fall further, raising inflation somewhat. The current account balance may turn negative. The government budget will move into deficit in 2016, as tax-benefit reforms reduce revenues and raise spending, but is projected to return to surplus in 2017 as higher excise taxes and economic growth boost revenues.

    The tax, disability-benefit and education reforms may boost employment and competitiveness more strongly than expected. Stronger euro area recovery would enable Estonia to expand its export markets and reinvigorate investment. On the other hand, major trading partners, in particular Russia and Finland, may experience a more prolonged economic slowdown than projected. Further escalation of the conflict in Ukraine could also undermine exports and investment. A further fall in oil prices would raise real household income but result in further downscaling of production in the oil shale industry. Although financial market turbulence in emerging market economies could spill over to Estonia, low debt levels, strong equity buffers in the banking sector and euro membership are likely to mitigate such risks.

    Euro Area

    The ongoing moderate recovery is projected to continue, with GDP growth reaching 1.7% in 2017. Sustained monetary stimulus and low oil prices will support domestic demand, but the slowdown in emerging market economies will weigh on exports. As a result, the large external surplus will decrease slightly. The decline in unemployment should also continue at a modest pace, but differences across euro area countries will persist. Continued cyclical slack and some second-round effects from cheaper energy will hold inflation well under the ECB’s target of just below 2%.

    Monetary policy should remain accommodative until inflation is clearly rising to the target. Completion of the banking union would improve monetary policy transmission and strengthen confidence. Countries with fiscal space should use fiscal stimulus to support aggregate demand, especially through infrastructure investment. Reforms of tax and spending policies, such as lowering taxes on labour and prioritising growth and equity-friendly spending, will increase jobs and living standards.

    Productivity growth has been very sluggish and has tended to become more dispersed across firms, reflecting insufficient diffusion of innovations. Enhanced public support for R&D and more effective adult learning would foster knowledge diffusion. But diffusion also occurs through investment, and better financing conditions are needed to increase dynamism, which requires faster resolution of non-performing loans and insolvencies. Completing the Single Market in network sectors and services is essential to raise productivity growth. Investment would also be strengthened by speeding up the implementation of the Juncker plan.

    A moderate recovery has continued

    Growth continued at a moderate pace in early 2016. As in the second half of 2015, domestic demand has been the main driver of activity, with private consumption, public consumption and investment all displaying some dynamism. However, the slowdown in global growth has weighed on exports. Unemployment has declined further but remains high. The sharp drop in oil and commodity prices reduced headline inflation to levels around zero. Cyclical slack, recent euro appreciation and declining inflation expectations have kept core inflation hovering somewhat below 1%.

    Economic performance has remained uneven from country to country, with only a modest reversal of the very divergent output and unemployment dynamics brought about by the sovereign debt crisis. Among the countries hit hardest, only Ireland and Spain have had growth clearly above the euro area average. The countries most affected by the crisis have largely or fully eliminated their current account deficits, but, in most cases, this reflects still weak domestic demand. Ireland and Spain again stand out for their stronger export growth, which is essential to avoid external deficits reappearing as the recovery continues.
