    Growth and equity need further support from fiscal, structural and financial sector policies

    Despite some improvement in credit conditions, the recovery in investment will be limited by modest growth prospects, uncertainty about developments in European integration and still high private sector debt. Private consumption remains hampered by labour market weakness and high indebtedness. Subdued global trade growth will limit export growth.

    Credit and Productivity

    Loans to non-financial corporations adjusted for sales and securitisation.

    Real GDP per person employed.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and European Central Bank.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367789

    In the euro area as whole, fiscal policy is projected to remain slightly expansionary in 2016 and 2017, which is a sharp contrast to the consolidation in the 2011-13 period. However, more support will be needed to move growth to a higher track. Some countries have room to provide additional fiscal support. In this context, well designed and chosen infrastructure investment is attractive in that it has a high short-term multiplier and lays the foundations for a more sustained expansion. In addition, tax and spending policy reforms can be growth and employment friendly. Decreasing labour taxation, especially for low earners, shifting the composition of expenditure towards investment, education and childcare, and increasing public spending efficiency would help to boost growth and make it more inclusive. Further efforts to strengthen national budgetary frameworks hold the promise of improving the quality of public finances.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369175

    In December 2015 and March 2016 the European Central Bank took additional expansionary measures, inter alia by decreasing policy rates, increasing the scope and size of asset purchases, and by providing stronger incentives for bank lending in another round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations. The very accommodative monetary conditions are assumed to persist over the projection horizon. To further spur credit growth and make it flow towards productive firms, faster resolution of non-performing loans is essential, and could be fostered by prudential tools and the setting up of asset management companies, possibly at the European level. To further reduce financial fragmentation and ease crisis management, a common backstop to the Single Resolution Fund and deposit insurance at the European level would be helpful.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369185

    Investment is still far below pre-crisis levels in many countries, which slows down productivity growth, notably by hindering the diffusion of innovation. While innovation gives a temporary advantage to leading firms, enabling them to pay higher wages, the full gains from innovations are realised only when they are diffused through the market. Completing the Single Market in services and network sectors would spur investment by increasing competition and reducing regulatory burdens (in part by harmonising regulation). In turn, market integration would benefit from faster deployment of Trans-European transport and energy networks. Improving the availability and effectiveness of lifelong learning and job-related training would enhance knowledge diffusion and labour reallocation towards high-productivity firms.

    External indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369193

    Mild growth is projected for the coming quarters

    GDP growth is projected to accelerate modestly to 1.7% in 2017. Monetary stimulus and cheap oil should continue to support private consumption and investment, and fiscal policy in the area as a whole will no longer be a brake on demand. Though gradually recovering, export growth will remain subdued throughout most of the projection horizon, and the large current account surplus will decline only slightly. Unemployment is projected to fall, but it will remain high in a number of countries. Due to cyclical slack and low inflation expectations, core inflation is projected to increase only slightly and remain well below 2%.

    A decision by the United Kingdom to leave the European Union could significantly weaken growth across the euro area through higher risk premia, lower asset prices, and euro appreciation vis-à-vis the sterling. Financial turbulence in emerging market economies, induced by high corporate indebtedness or other vulnerabilities, would weaken demand for euro area exports and could also harm investment through higher interest rates. Lower-than-expected inflation would compound deleveraging challenges, but could boost real wages. Faster progress in cleaning up banks’ balance sheets and reforming product markets, spending and tax policies, in tandem with regained momentum in European integration, would boost GDP growth.

    Finland

    The economy is recovering slowly on the back of strengthening domestic demand. However, exports remain weak, the recent pick-up in private consumption was partly due to temporary factors and uncertainty, both domestic and global, is high. Hence, output growth is projected to remain sluggish and unemployment, which is currently stabilising, to stay high.

    The euro area monetary policy stance is supporting the recovery, but fiscal consolidation exerts a drag. The government has embarked on an ambitious structural reform programme to enhance competitiveness, labour market flexibility and fiscal sustainability. However, it is facing resistance, which risks delaying growth-enhancing reforms. The uncertainty regarding policy may weigh on the recovery.

    Productivity has declined since 2007. Although this mainly results from poor performance in manufacturing and notably information and communication technologies, the service sector has also tended to underperform. Policies need to enhance framework conditions further and support innovation to revive investment and foster inclusive growth.

    Growth is picking up slowly

    Output growth is driven by private consumption and investment. However, exports are being held back by the recession in Russia, weak global demand and eroded competitiveness. Low inflation is lifting household real disposable income and consumption, although some policies to support consumption in 2015 have expired. Following a long slump, investment is starting to rise again. Low interest rates and migration into growth centres is raising residential construction, while large-scale projects are lifting business investment. Unemployment shows signs of stabilisation, albeit at a high level. The fiscal deficit is back under 3% of GDP, thanks to spending containment and increasing tax revenues.

    Trade and investment

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367794

    The government is struggling to implement structural reforms

    The government is facing opposition to some of its plans to enhance labour market flexibility and improve competitiveness, as well as to some of its intended public spending cuts. Hence, the extent and timing of the reforms remain uncertain. Fiscal consolidation efforts, assumed to be about half a percentage point of GDP per year, exert a drag on growth, even though spending cuts are partly offset by strategic expenditure on key government projects financed through balance-sheet transactions. However, expansionary euro area monetary policy and relatively easy access to credit are supporting growth.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369276

    Successful implementation of the government’s programme would raise employment and productivity, thereby fostering inclusive growth. A recently announced entrepreneurship programme will use wage subsidies start-up grants and tax incentives to encourage companies to hire their first employees. The government has initiated social welfare and health care reform to raise public-sector productivity and reduce health and social inequalities. Streamlining land-use planning regulations would improve housing affordability and allow productivity gains in retail trade.

    The recovery is facing headwinds

    The recovery is being driven by domestic demand but needs further impulse from exports to gather speed, especially as the temporary factors which have been boosting consumption have expired. The investment recovery is broad-based and set to continue. Residential investment is fuelled by low interest rates and high demand in growth centres, while major commercial building projects are underway. Investment in machinery and equipment is rising, including for capacity expansion, as utilisation rates increase, notably in the forest and metal industries. Such investments will raise productivity, which has been lacklustre over recent years. Nevertheless, projected growth will be too weak to markedly reduce unemployment, even if policies enhance labour market flexibility. Inflation is set to remain subdued. The fiscal deficit will decline slowly, as consolidation measures are partly offset by rising ageing-related costs.

    As a small open economy, Finland is sensitive to developments in the global economy and particularly in Nordic countries, Germany and Russia, which implies both downside and upside risks. Worsening geopolitical tensions, a further economic slowdown in China or increased volatility in emerging market economies and oil prices could disrupt the recovery. The ability of the government to implement its programme in the face of public resistance conditions medium-term growth and fiscal sustainability. In the short term, uncertainty over reform implementation and potential industrial action could weigh on the recovery.

    France

    Economic growth is projected to reach 1.4% this year and 1.5% in 2017 thanks to lower energy prices, tax cuts on labour and businesses and persistently low interest rates. Employment will increase, supported by lower social security contributions and new hiring subsidies, but will lead to only a gradual fall in unemployment. Inflation will remain low, as slack will persist to the end of the forecast period.

    Despite tax reductions, lower debt-servicing costs and some spending restraint should bring the fiscal deficit down to 3% of GDP in 2017. This will limit further increases in public debt, while minimising risks to the still fragile recovery. To fight high unemployment the authorities announced new hiring subsidies for small and medium‑sized firms and up-scaled training measures for jobseekers. A draft labour market reform clarifies conditions for dismissals for economic reasons and gives more room for firm-level negotiations, mainly as to working time.

    The level of productivity is high, but productivity growth has been weak for several decades. Quickly implementing the foreseen quality assurance and guidance systems for training would help foster the inclusion of low-skilled workers in the workplace by strengthening their productivity. Greater legal certainty for dismissals would make firms more willing to hire and take chances on expansion, offering more stable jobs. Easing entry into a wider range of regulated professions would enhance competition and productivity, thereby lowering prices to the benefit of consumers, especially poor ones.

    A gradual recovery has taken hold

    Falling energy prices and low inflation have led to rising real wages, supporting stronger private consumption growth. Business investment began to rebound in 2015, thanks to strong profits, low energy prices, accelerated depreciation allowances, and cuts in social contributions and business taxes. However, public-sector spending restraint has led to declining local government investment. Residential investment is still contracting although building permits and housing starts have levelled off since early 2015.

    Investment and inflation

    As a percentage of gross value added.

    Harmonised consumer price index, excluding energy, food, alcohol, and tobacco for core inflation.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and INSEE.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367801

    A lower euro and tax reductions have helped French exporters restore their competitiveness and regain market share, while cheaper oil has lowered the cost of imports. This has led to a substantial decline in the external deficit. The rise in the unemployment rate has stopped, thanks to subsidised jobs for young and low-skilled workers, mainly in the non-market sector, and more recently growth in temporary agency jobs. Despite extremely accommodative monetary policy, widespread excess capacity and falling oil prices have pushed inflation down.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369024

    Labour tax cuts and training reform promote employment and productivity of low‑skilled workers

    Owing to sharp cuts in local government investment the general government deficit fell to 3.5% of GDP in 2015, lower than had been expected. Spending restraint and the pick‑up in economic growth will help the government lower the deficit further to the target of 3% of GDP in 2017, notwithstanding a number of measures that will increase spending. This gradual pace of consolidation is appropriate, given the still fragile recovery.

    Consumption and employment

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367816

    A number of recent and envisaged reforms could help improve the productivity and employment chances of lower-skilled workers. Following a 2014 reform the unemployed will receive rights to additional training hours. The envisaged reform to improve legal certainty regarding dismissals would make employers more willing to hire on open-ended contracts and this could improve chances to obtain more stable employment for low‑skilled workers, many of whom work currently on short-term contracts with poor access to training. That said, this would come at the cost of increasing risks to be dismissed for workers who already have an open-ended contract today. The cuts in social contributions mainly targeted at low-wage workers will also increase labour-market inclusiveness. However, as the measure is phased out as income rises, the associated increase in taxes could weaken incentives to participate in training and create low-wage traps. Further personal income tax cuts on low- and middle-income households, streamlined and more effective in-work benefits and additional reductions in employers’ social contributions will improve employment chances of low-wage workers, supporting consumption and making growth more inclusive. The recent product market reform should be extended to a wider range of regulated professions and retail regulation should be further eased, in order to expand job opportunities.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369039

    Growth is projected to increase gradually

    Further social security contribution cuts and new hiring subsidies should support a moderate pace of employment and private consumption growth. The recently announced extension of the accelerated depreciation allowance beyond April 2016 and lower business taxes and employers’ social security contributions will underpin gains in business investment. Residential investment should bottom out around mid-year, but the subsequent pick-up will be modest. Exports are expected to grow broadly in line with external demand.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369045

    This is a central scenario, and a number of factors could lead to different outcomes. The series of recent reforms could strengthen household and business confidence more than expected, leading to stronger consumption and investment following recent increases in the household savings rate and profit margins. On the other hand, a stronger-than-expected slowdown in emerging market economies, notably China, or lower euro area growth, e.g. related to a vote for Brexit, could hit external demand and confidence.

    Germany

    Economic growth is projected to remain solid, as a robust labour market and low oil prices underpin private consumption, while low interest rates and the housing needs of refugees boost residential investment. Business investment will strengthen somewhat, as capacity utilisation and employment rise. Demand for German exports in emerging market economies and euro area countries are expected to recover gradually. The refugees will gradually join the labour force. Robust domestic demand growth will reduce the current account surplus, which will nevertheless remain very large.

    The budgetary stance is mildly expansionary, which is appropriate as spending room is available to improve the integration of immigrants and to strengthen active labour market policies for those who have difficulties finding work. In addition, gaps remain in the provision of early childhood education and care, full-day primary schooling and transport infrastructure. The education system should provide more support for youth with a weak socio-economic background. These measures would boost the inclusiveness of the ongoing economic expansion, and are an investment to raise growth in the future.

    Productivity has grown little in recent years and is relatively low in services. Accelerating refugees’ access to the labour market and further raising their skills would expand output, reduce dependence on public support and include refugees more rapidly in society. Reducing the high taxes on second earners would remove barriers for women to work full-time, improving access to more productive jobs and careers. Reforms to remove barriers to entry and competition in professional services and network industries would strengthen productivity and investment and could reduce the current account surplus.

    Domestic demand is supporting activity but skill mismatch holds back productivity

    Activity expanded vigorously in the first quarter, especially in construction, which was boosted by unusually mild winter weather. Wages and employment rose, while low oil prices damped consumer prices, boosting private household consumption. Government employment has risen to deal with the needs of refugees. About 1 million refugees arrived in 2015 (1¼ per cent of the population). Most of them have not yet started looking for a job, as asylum procedures and first training measures are being completed. Unemployment remains at historical lows. However, close to one half of the unemployed have been looking for a job for more than a year, while at the same time skill shortages are contributing to rising vacancies. Barriers in the tax system and only limited full-day childcare and schooling hold back full-time female employment, restraining women’s careers and productivity.

    Rising household incomes and the large number of refugees have boosted demand for housing, pushing up rents and prices in urban centres and spurring construction. Nonetheless, lending to households remains modest. Foreign orders for investment goods, on which German manufacturing is specialised, have weakened. Exports to China, which absorb 7% of German merchandise exports, have fallen.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368998

    Immigration and higher government spending are boosting domestic demand

    Many refugees will start entering the labour market in the second half of 2016, once their asylum requests have been processed. Since they have no German language skills and most lack formal qualifications, many will not find jobs quickly. The government has taken stock of immigrants’ skills, expanded training opportunities and facilitated access to the education system. It is planning to ease legal barriers for asylum-seekers to look for a job. In view of the young age of many immigrants, such steps have a high long-term pay-off.

    Labour market and real wages

    Government spending to receive and integrate immigrants is expected to increase by ¼ per cent of GDP in each of 2016 and 2017. Spending for child benefits, child tax allowances and long-term care benefits will rise by 0.2% of GDP. The child tax allowances have little impact on labour supply or poverty reduction, whereas the child benefit supplement for low-income children reduces poverty risk. Government investment spending for transport infrastructure, broadband networks, energy efficiency, housing, childcare facilities, universities and other research institutions will also increase by 0.2% of GDP. The supply of childcare facilities is progressing, helping to reconcile professional and family lives, but gaps remain, and most primary schools continue to provide teaching only in the morning. The federal government has also made higher transfers to local governments for investment and plans to create a long-distance road infrastructure corporation, to which it has assigned the revenues of road use charges. Most of the additional spending will make economic growth more inclusive.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369002

    Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth

    Economic growth is projected to remain robust, driven by private household demand and higher government spending. Strong domestic demand will push up consumer prices somewhat, as the impact of low oil prices fades and wages grow more strongly than productivity. Unemployment is expected to rise somewhat. World trade and investment in key trading partners are expected to remain subdued, damping exports. Moreover, the euro has appreciated and strong wage growth will reduce Germany’s competitiveness. Strong tax revenue growth and declining debt servicing costs are expected to keep the government budget in surplus, notwithstanding rising spending.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369011

    A sharp slowdown of activity in emerging market economies and protracted weak demand in the euro area would weaken exports and investment. Rising geopolitical tensions would affect the export-oriented German economy particularly strongly. An exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union would also increase uncertainty about trade and investment prospects. If they materialise, these risks would spill over to consumer confidence and financial markets. Lower oil prices would boost household consumption and business profitability but could also contribute to global financial market turbulence. The low leverage ratios in systemically important banks could aggravate the consequences of financial market turbulence. On the other hand, steps to implement reforms to complete the Single Market in the European Union and establish a comprehensive banking union in the Euro Area could boost exports and the attractiveness of Germany as a location to invest. Adopting policies to deal with domestic long-term challenges, notably with respect to population ageing and long-term greenhouse gas emission reduction targets, could boost investment in the near term.

    Greece

    Growth is projected to turn positive in the second half of 2016, after a deep and prolonged recession, as recovering confidence boosts investment and consumption and improved competitiveness raises exports. Unemployment is still very high, which is causing serious social problems, but is now gradually receding. The huge public debt burden is undermining investment and confidence, making some form of additional debt relief (for example, extending maturities) crucial.

    The pace of fiscal consolidation has slowed. This is appropriate given the need for growth and rising fiscal pressures, including from the refugee crisis. The implementation of policies such as the Guaranteed Minimum Income and school meal and housing programmes will reduce poverty and inequality, which rose sharply during the crisis. Fighting tax evasion would increase fairness and raise the revenues needed to deal with social problems. Dealing with the large stock of non-performing loans in banks is a priority to restore the availability of credit for investment.

    Persistently weak productivity performance accounts for a significant part of the decline in output since the onset of the crisis. The full implementation of structural reforms will boost productivity and growth. Labour market reforms have improved flexibility and thereby productivity. Productivity growth will also be boosted by easing the regulatory burden and barriers to competition further, especially in network industries and protected professions, and increasing the efficiency of bankruptcy procedures.

    The economy is recovering gradually from a deep recession

    The financing programme agreed with the European Stability Mechanism in August 2015 has reduced uncertainty and, together with the gradual softening of capital controls, boosted confidence and growth. Investment rebounded in the last quarter of 2015. Job creation improved and the high unemployment rate declined further. The inadequate social safety net has been unable to stem the rise in poverty. Inflation was still negative at the end of 2015 due to large spare capacity and falling oil prices.

    Confidence and Unit labour costs

    Unweighted average of data for manufacturing industry, construction, trade and business-related services.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and OECD National Accounts Database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367848

    Despite the recapitalisation of banks last December credit conditions are still sluggish due to large non-performing loans. Due to continuing fiscal consolidation, the primary balance became positive at 0.7% of GDP in 2015, outperforming the target of -0.25% of GDP. Public debt is still very high, however, bearing on investment and confidence.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369286

    Policies to reduce poverty and structural reforms are needed for more inclusive growth

    The slower pace of consolidation set out in the August agreement is appropriate. The implementation of planned social policies, such as the Guaranteed Minimum Income, would alleviate poverty and help to deal with the high social costs of the crisis. The modernisation of the public employment service and the expansion of active labour market policies would reduce unemployment. Fighting tax evasion and rationalising the pension system will raise revenues to finance these policies.

    The full implementation of the structural reforms agreed under the August agreement will significantly boost output over the next decade. Further reforms are needed to shift the economic structure towards exports and the expansion of new enterprises. Easing regulation in network industries will increase competitiveness and enhance exports. Further reducing regulatory procedures and administrative burdens on firms will enhance productivity and investment.

    The recovery is expected to gain strength but uncertainty remains high

    Output growth is projected to turn positive only in the second half of 2016 but the economy should recover in 2017 as structural reforms spur domestic demand and stronger external demand enhances exports. Increases in VAT will raise headline inflation temporarily in 2016, but inflation will stay negative or close to zero given the large economic slack. Unemployment will continue to decline alleviating poverty further.

    Successful negotiations to lower the gross financing needs of the public sector could significantly improve the medium-term outlook by addressing debt sustainability risks. Full and swift implementation of structural reforms would boost confidence and lead to a stronger and faster economic recovery; but slippage in this area will be harmful for growth. Rising global risks such as weaker global trade, low oil prices and weaker growth in China and the euro area would reduce Greek exports. The cost of the refugee crisis, estimated at 0.4% of GDP for 2015, could be higher in 2016.

    Hungary

    Growth is projected to moderate in 2016 due to a temporary contraction in public investment as a new cycle of EU structural funds commences, but should pick up again in 2017. Private demand should remain solid and employment should continue to expand, supported in part by the still large public work schemes. The disappearance of economic slack and the one-off effects of lower energy prices will push up inflation during 2017.

    The fiscal stance will be broadly neutral in 2016, but is set to become expansionary in 2017 even though economic slack will largely be eliminated. The public work schemes (which cost ½ per cent of GDP) should be gradually scaled down as employment opportunities in the private labour market expand. With rising inflation, the central bank may need to consider moving towards a more neutral policy stance by end-2017.

    Productivity growth has been low since the global financial crisis. Broad structural reforms are needed to secure more competitive firms and an adequately skilled labour force. In particular, red tape should be cut and regulatory impact assessments should be better used to improve transparency, stability and formulation of regulatory policies. The effectiveness of labour market training programmes should be enhanced together with measures to improve vocational training, work-family balance and lifelong learning. A comprehensive SME strategy could increase economic dynamism and inclusiveness.

    Growth is driven by domestic demand

    The economy contracted in early 2016. A major factor was the slower disbursement of EU structural funds in the beginning of the new funding cycle, which has cut public investment. Business sector investment has also been lacklustre despite an increase in demand, still high business confidence and favourable credit conditions. On the other hand, private consumption has accelerated on the back of rising real incomes and the strength of consumer confidence. Exports in 2015 benefitted from past currency depreciation, but have slowed in line with the deceleration in export markets.

    Confidence and labour market

    Thomson Reuters; Hungarian Central Statistical Office.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367853

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369296

    Employment growth is being mainly driven by the private sector, although the expanding public work schemes continue to be an important factor behind the fall in unemployment. Bottlenecks have started to appear in the labour market and wage growth is increasing. Inflation is hovering around zero as the result of falling energy prices; core inflation, which removes food and energy, is about 1½ per cent.

    Macroeconomic policies are supporting growth

    The fiscal policy stance is now broadly neutral in 2016, but will become expansionary in 2017 as public investment, public wages and housing subsidies are set to rise. However, in view of tightening cyclical conditions, such an expansion could increase economic tensions. In the first half of 2016, the central bank lowered again its policy rate twice, to 0.9% – a level that the bank judges to be in line with the medium-term achievement of its 3% inflation target, signalling an end to the policy rate cutting cycle.

    The central bank’s use of unconventional monetary policy is evolving. The funding for growth schemes, which provide liquidity to banks for SME lending, are being phased out during 2016 and replaced by the Market-Based Lending Scheme where the central bank will assume some of the interest rate risks for loans to SMEs, reduce supervisory risk weights on loans to SMEs, and provide credit data for better risk assessments. While support for SMEs may be helpful in raising economic dynamism, reduced risk weights may lead banks to take on too much risk. With both monetary policy and supervisory responsibilities, the central bank is in a position to monitor these trade-offs closely.

    After a pause, growth is expected to accelerate in 2017

    For 2016, economic growth is projected to slow temporarily as public investment contracts, reflecting lower disbursement of EU structural funds at the beginning of a new funding cycle. Economic activity is projected to pick up during the course of the year and into 2017. Private consumption is set to expand strongly as real incomes are boosted by higher employment, lower personal income taxes, lower VAT rates on selected products, and a new family housing programme. Exporters are expected to continue to gain market shares, which will raise the current account surplus further. Sustained private employment growth and public work schemes will continue to drive down unemployment. Inflation is projected to edge up, despite the reduction in VAT rates, as the temporary effects of lower energy prices run their course and economic slack diminishes.

    If the employment content of growth surprises on the upside, private consumption could accelerate further. Likewise, if the measures to advance infrastructure investment are more effective than envisaged, growth could be stronger in 2016. External risks are mostly negative. A weaker-than-projected recovery in world trade would hurt exports. Financial turmoil in Europe could force the central bank to tighten its policy rate earlier than assumed now. If temporary border controls recently put in place by several countries are maintained, this could hamper the free movement of goods and cross-border labour, hurting Hungarian workers and exporters.

    Iceland

    The economy continues its robust expansion, driven by strong private consumption growth, a terms-of-trade boost and a boom in tourism. Large investments in energy-intensive projects and continued strong wage growth are fuelling domestic demand. The capital controls introduced during the financial crisis will begin to be lifted in 2016.

    Inflation has been modest in early 2016 at around 2%, and has been held down by exchange rate appreciation and falling energy prices. However, underlying inflationary pressures are strong and monetary policy should therefore remain tight, which will slow growth in 2017. Fiscal policy is eased in 2016, but still targets a primary surplus, which coupled with windfall receipts arising from the lifting of capital controls will bring down government debt.

    Labour productivity growth has been negligible since the crisis. In part this reflects a compositional shift towards low-productivity sectors, such as tourism. Toughening competition policy to stop abuse of dominant positions and tacit collusion, and lowering legal barriers to entry would boost productivity growth.

    The economy is booming

    The economy continues its robust recovery, underpinned by strong private demand, a surge in investment activity and a boom in tourism. Household income continues to benefit from the double digit wage increases awarded in 2015. In March, wage growth accelerated to around 13% relative to a year earlier. These pay rises are far above productivity growth, which remains subdued, and will affect competitiveness. Employment growth has also been robust, bringing the unemployment rate down to just 3.1%. The tourism boom has continued and is supporting construction. In addition, investment in a number of energy-intensive projects is boosting business fixed investment during 2016.

    Wages and output and unemployment

    The output gap is the three-month centred moving average inverted.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and Statistics Iceland.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367863

    Macroeconomic policies need to tighten

    Inflation has remained below the central bank’s target of 2½ per cent, reflecting the appreciation of the Krona and the fall in energy prices. Longer-term inflation expectations have begun to stabilise, but some way above the central bank’s target. However, considerable inflationary pressure has built up, not least owing to the high wage increases. The central bank needs to prevent a wage-price spiral emerging and establish monetary policy credibility if it is to achieve low and stable inflation. The projections assume that the short term interest rates on 7-day deposits will rise above 6% from the second quarter of 2016.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369306

    The budgetary position has improved substantially and a surplus is assumed for 2016 and 2017, although the underlying primary balance will deteriorate somewhat. Substantial windfall receipts, expected to be around 13% of GDP, from agreements with the estates of the failed banks (part of the plan to lift of capital controls) should be used to reduce public debt as planned, thereby reducing high interest payments. Given demand pressures, fiscal policy should tighten to prevent overheating.

    Lethargic productivity growth in part reflects the shifting composition of the economy towards tourism, but productivity is generally weak except in fishing and energy-intensive metallurgy. The small size of the economy can limit opportunities. However, a number of artificial barriers and anti-competitive behaviour of incumbents limit competitive pressures. Reducing barriers to entry and enforcing competition policy robustly to prevent abuse of dominant position or tacit collusion would boost productivity.

    Output growth will remain robust with risks of overheating

    Robust income growth and investment will support the economy in 2016. Maintaining a relatively tight monetary policy combined with the moderation of investments in energy-intensive projects will eventually begin to slow the economy and slacken employment growth, edging up the unemployment rate. However, wage increases remain particularly strong and the danger of a wage-price spiral is acute. In an election year it is imperative for macroeconomic policy to remain tight. Fiscal policy needs to resist calls for relaxation when the large windfall receipts from reaching agreements with bank resolution committees are received.

    India

    Economic growth is projected to remain strong, hovering around 7.5%. Private consumption will be boosted by expected large increases in public wages and declining inflation. Investment will pick up gradually as excess capacity fades, deleveraging continues for corporations and banks, and infrastructure projects mature.

    Inflation is above the long-term target and public debt is high, leaving little room for accommodative policies. However, some monetary impulse is to come as recent cuts in policy rates are passed on to consumers and investors. The renewed commitment for fiscal consolidation is welcome but the quality of public finances should be improved by increasing tax revenue and tilting the spending mix towards physical and social infrastructure. Creating more and better quality jobs is the key to inclusive growth and requires modernising labour laws and making further progress in the ease of doing business.

    Improving productivity is essential for India’s GDP per capita to catch up with higher-income countries. In the agriculture sector, which still absorbs about half of total employment, this would require farm consolidation and mechanisation as well as better storage and transport infrastructure. In the manufacturing sector, labour and product market regulations should be reformed to enable firms to expand to an efficient size. Providing better access to quality health and education systems is also key, both to raise productivity and to ensure its fruits are spread more equitably.

    India remains one of the fastest growing countries

    Private consumption in urban areas has been buoyed by prospects of higher public wages and pensions combined with declining inflation. Government investment and consumption have been strong. However, demand in rural areas has suffered from two consecutive years of bad weather. Moreover, private investment has failed to pick up, reflecting low capacity utilisation rates, the weak financial position of some corporations and high non-performing loans in public banks. While the government has succeeded in fast-tracking public infrastructure projects, stalled investment projects have again risen to more than 8% of GDP, with the private sector accounting for the bulk of the delays. Acquiring land and getting clearances remain difficult. Inflation has remained contained, helped by subdued commodity prices, active management of food stocks to avoid spikes in food prices and still low capacity utilisation in the industrial sector.

    Growth and job creation

    Job creation in enterprises with at least 10 employees in 8 industries (textiles including apparels; leather; metals; automobiles; gems and jewellery; transport; information technology or business process outsourcing; and handloom and powerloom).

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and Government of India, Labour Bureau.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367876

    Job creation in the organised sector (enterprises with 10 or more employees) has been slow, leaving most workers in the unorganised sector, with little job protection, training opportunities and social coverage as well as much lower compensation. The participation rate of women is low and when women work, they tend to have marginal jobs. Despite equal pay laws, gender wage gaps are large. Overall, almost half of total employment remains in the agriculture sector while manufacturing employment is concentrated in small enterprises. This employment pattern weighs on labour productivity.

    Macroeconomic indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369492

    External vulnerabilities remain relatively low. The decline in merchandise imports, driven by subdued commodity prices and weak business investment, has contributed to keeping the current account deficit at about 1½ per cent of GDP. Exports have been weak but net foreign direct investment has rebounded and more than fully financed the current account deficit in 2015.

    Lending rates and bank assets

    Reserve Bank of India.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367886

    Macroeconomic policies have improved but structural reforms lag behind

    CPI inflation stood at 4.9% in FY 2015-16, allowing the Reserve Bank to cut again policy rates in April 2016. However, there is little room left for further cuts as inflation expectations remain stubbornly high and the 4% CPI inflation target over the medium term is, in historical terms, ambitious. Recent measures to improve monetary policy transmission should gradually be reflected in lower lending rates, supporting the economy.

    High ratios of public debt and deficits to GDP do not leave much room for fiscal policy to support growth. The large increase in public wages and pensions, recommended by the 7th Pay Commission, and the need to recapitalise banks and clean up balance sheets of states’ power distribution companies, are likely to put the public finances under strain. To finance much-needed social and physical infrastructure programmes, there is scope to raise more revenue from personal income and property taxes and to further rationalise subsidy programmes. Efforts to recognise stressed assets, to clean up banks’ balance sheets and to avoid a future build-up of bad loans are necessary for investment to revive, although they may have a negative impact in the short run. The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code passed in May 2016, which replaces multiple laws dealing with insolvency and sets a time limit for the resolution of insolvency, is a welcome step.

    The lack of a majority in the upper chamber of parliament has made it difficult to pass some of the long-awaited structural reforms, including the unified value added tax (GST), land acquisition reform and labour laws. Such measures are urgently needed to boost productivity and employment in the manufacturing sector, which has remained under-developed compared to other emerging market economies. Meeting the aspirations of a rapidly growing working-age population, still largely rural, will also require training programmes and specific support to populations at risk.

    Some states have taken advantage of the new federalism framework to modernise regulations and improve the ease of doing business. Evaluating the impact of states’ reforms and sharing best practices across states would support the reform process.

    Domestic demand will remain buoyant

    Private consumption will remain the main source of demand. The return to normal weather conditions after two years of poor monsoon should support agriculture production and consumption in rural areas. Buoyant private consumption should gradually spur more private investment to meet that demand. Inflation will continue to decline, as the effectiveness and credibility of monetary policy strengthen and weather conditions improve.

    The economy could grow faster and create more and better quality employment if parliament passed key reforms, including the GST, land acquisition and labour laws. Financial risks could undermine growth prospects. Some corporations are highly leveraged, with large unhedged foreign positions. Non-performing assets and restructured loans are weighing on public banks’ ability to extend loans and finance investment projects. India could also suffer from more volatile capital flows, exchange rates and financial markets. However, external vulnerabilities have declined as the current account deficit has narrowed, FDI has rebounded and external reserves have increased.

    Indonesia

    GDP growth is set to strengthen in coming quarters. The government’s plan to ramp up infrastructure spending has now gained traction, boosting confidence. In addition, the central bank has eased rates over three consecutive months. As a result, both private consumption and investment are showing signs of picking up. However, external demand remains weak.

    The government has recently released a series of reform packages to streamline investment, liberalise FDI and improve the business climate. There should be scope for further interest rate cuts in the medium term, as inflation should remain subdued and the exchange rate firm. However, the fiscal balance could deteriorate owing to lower commodity prices, which, in light of the 3% of GDP deficit ceiling, may constrain future public spending.

    Although in line with its stage of development, productivity levels are low in Indonesia. More needs to be done to facilitate the transformation of the economy away from low-productivity sectors, such as agriculture, and towards manufacturing and services. Infrastructure bottlenecks, impediments to foreign investment and inflexible labour market regulations are barriers to greater participation in global value chains. Regulatory uncertainty, related to overlapping central and regional jurisdictions, is also restraining private investment.

    Activity has been muted by weak external conditions and impaired confidence

    Growth has been weak in recent quarters, with low prices for Indonesia's commodity exports and limited demand from major trading partners putting a damper on economic activity. Private consumption and business investment have both been soft. Moreover, the fragile currency and above-target inflation previously prevented monetary policy from becoming more expansionary.

    Infrastructure and monetary policy

    2015 and 2016 are OECD estimates.

    Statistics Indonesia (BPS); Ministry of finance of Indonesia; and Bank Indonesia.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367891

    Macroeconomic policies are accommodative

    Bank Indonesia has cut interest rates three months in a row, to 6.75%. Inflation has fallen to 4.5%, within the target range of 4±1%. In contrast with the trend depreciation over the past several years, the rupiah has staged a recent rebound against the dollar, appreciating by about 5%.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369501

    Spending on infrastructure is increasing after the government created significant fiscal space by abolishing fossil fuel subsidies. Nevertheless, revenue shortfalls are now emerging, largely related to low commodity prices, and the deficit is in danger of the breaching the 3% of GDP limit. To forestall this possibility, the government has recently announced plans to revise the 2016 budget and cut expenditure. But to ensure the fiscal resources for critical policies needed for long-term growth, including a broader social safety net to ensure growth is widely spread, the government needs to step up efforts to improve tax collection.

    Structural reforms to improve the business environment are welcome

    The government has recently released a series of welcome reform packages, which have focused on improving the business climate, including by removing impediments to foreign investment. It has also recently committed to providing guarantees for private participation in 30 high-priority infrastructure projects and substantially reformed special economic zones. As well as taking measures to boost revenues, there is ample scope to improve public spending efficiency, thereby making room for expanding inclusive social programmes.

    Productivity should benefit from these recent reforms, although more needs to be done to make the labour market more flexible, especially in light of the need to bring more workers out of the large informal sector into the formal sector, where jobs are better. Regulatory uncertainty related to overlapping central and regional jurisdictions is also holding back private sector investment as well as weakening enforcement of environmental regulations. This risks a recurrence of 2015's devastating forest fires.

    Growth is set to firm, but external uncertainties could temper confidence

    GDP growth is expected to pick up over the course of 2016 and firm further in 2017. Despite continuing weak external conditions, with government investment gathering pace, inflation moderating and the rupiah firming, confidence is returning. Motor vehicle sales are starting to turn around, credit growth is picking up, and business sentiment has also started to recover, pointing to stronger consumption and a rebound in business investment.

    If external conditions worsen significantly, especially in major export markets like China, and the current balance deteriorates further, the exchange rate may come under renewed pressure, and the monetary authorities would have to delay further interest rate cuts. If oil and other commodity prices fall further and budget revenues continue to weaken, the government could hit the 3% of GDP deficit ceiling and be forced to pull back on infrastructure spending. If the shift from public to private participation in infrastructure investment does not happen, activity will weaken and confidence would suffer. Given Indonesia’s exposure to external sources of funding, volatility in financial markets also poses a risk.

    Ireland

    The Irish economy is projected to continue its robust expansion in 2016 and 2017. Both exports and business investment, which surged due to temporary impetus by multinational enterprises, will moderate but remain solid. Activity in the domestic sector will remain firm and employment will grow steadily. Wage growth will be strong as the labour market tightens. Household consumption will be solid, supported by labour earnings growth and tax cuts.

    The government is assumed to remain on track towards its medium-term goal of balancing the budget. The overall balance is projected to improve, but owing largely to cyclical conditions. Strong revenue growth and low interest costs should be primarily used for a more rapid reduction of still high public debt. Structural reforms should prioritise getting more people back into work by enhancing activation policy, which would spread the benefits of increased prosperity widely across society.

    Productivity growth has been trending down for some time, in association with a slowdown in knowledge-based capital (KBC) investment. The recent surge in KBC investment by multinational enterprises will lift productivity growth. However, the diffusion of innovation to smaller, national firms is likely to be limited by the weak linkages with multinationals. Public support to business R&D, which is skewed towards R&D tax credits, should be rebalanced towards more direct support for domestic SMEs.

    Growth has become broad-based, lifted also by temporary impetus

    The strength of the Irish economy has become broad-based. The unusually strong expansion in 2015 was driven by multinational enterprises, but activity in the domestic sector also gained ground. Both business investment (even excluding multinationals) and employment have grown solidly. The unemployment rate fell to 9%, although the employment rate remains still low. Private consumption grew strongly in 2015, reflecting the strong momentum of household disposable income, driven by employment gains, income tax cuts and low energy prices.

    Exports and households consumption

    Export performance is a ratio of the country’s total real exports to a weighted sum of the total real imports of its trade partners, with weights reflecting the share of the country’s exports to a particular trade partner in its total exports.

    Export market is a weighted sum of the total real imports of country’s trade partners, with weights reflecting the share of the country’s exports to a particular trade partner in its total exports.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367901

    Policy should aim to make growth sustainable and inclusive

    Financial conditions have improved on the back of monetary easing by the European Central Bank. The full return to normal credit supply is, however, hindered by the persistence of non-performing bank loans. The lending interest rates for SMEs remain among the highest in the euro area. New lending, although accelerating, is still outpaced by debt repayment in both the non-financial corporate and household sectors. The rise in property prices has been tempered, thanks to macro-prudential measures, but very low interest rates and housing supply shortages risk boosting prices again.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369317

    Fiscal policy is projected to be somewhat less contractionary than in past years, reflecting higher expenditures planned by the authorities, including a fiscal package of 1.5 billion euros for 2016. Nevertheless, most of the improvement will reflect stronger output growth, which raises taxes and reduces certain spending. Given the vigorous expansion, the government should avoid more fiscal stimulus than currently planned in order to prevent overheating pressures. Structural reforms should prioritise getting more people back into work by enhancing the efficiency of public employment services so that growth can become more sustainable.

    The economy will expand robustly but risks are significant

    The economy is projected to expand solidly, but with tightening capacity pushing up inflation. Exports will increase in line with demand of trading partners. Business investment should grow solidly given improved profitability prospects, although tight credit conditions will continue to exert a drag. Employment will grow steadily while labour force participation will rise. Wage growth is projected to become stronger as the labour market tightens. Household consumption will be solid as labour earnings grow further, although debt repayment is likely to keep its momentum in check.

    Wage growth may turn out to be much stronger than projected, lifting demand in the short run but fuelling further inflationary pressures and eroding competitiveness. Fiscal policy may prove more expansionary than assumed, as there will be a temptation to spend the extra revenue that very high growth will bring. This would also fuel demand pressures. The potential exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union would significantly affect the Irish economy. Irish exports to the United Kingdom, accounting for 20% of its overall exports, would be particularly sensitive to any raising of trade barriers or a sharp depreciation of sterling.

    Israel*

    The statistical data for Israel are supplied by and under the responsibility of the relevant Israeli authorities. The use of such data by the OECD is without prejudice to the status of the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and Israeli settlements in the West Bank under the terms of international law.

    Growth is projected to remain at 2½ per cent in 2016 before rising to 3% in 2017. An expansionary budget and continuing low interest rates and oil prices should support domestic demand and employment. Exports have been very weak of late but should pick up with a gradual strengthening of foreign demand, albeit damped by the shekel's appreciation.

    Given very low inflation and highly expansionary global monetary policies, continuing the current accommodative domestic monetary policy is desirable to prevent currency appreciation. Persisting tension on the property market still needs close monitoring by the authorities. Tax cuts and increased government spending in 2016 will boost the economy in the short term but will also complicate attaining the public debt reduction objective in the medium term.

    The catching-up process and social cohesion could be enhanced by stronger productivity in sheltered sectors, which often have a low-skilled workforce. Current efforts to stimulate competition in these sectors, especially agriculture and banking, are most welcome and should be pursued to increase purchasing power. Improvements in public transport and a more effective education system to facilitate the integration of under-privileged groups into the labour market would also increase the efficiency of the economy and public well-being.

    The weak external environment continues to weigh on growth

    After a jump in late 2015, growth slowed sharply at the beginning of 2016. The combination of weak external demand and a high exchange rate hit exports, which had recovered somewhat at the end of 2015. Following the pattern of recent years, the main economic driver remains consumer spending, buoyed by increased employment and real wages, supported by higher minimum wages, and low interest rates. With easy access to credit, businesses increased their investmentin late 2015 and early 2016. Strong housing construction benefitted from government support. Unemployment remains low, at around 5¼ per cent, and prices continue to decline, under the impact of falling costs of imports and oil and cuts in VAT and some public tariffs. While confortable at 4½ per cent of GDP in 2015, the current account surplus declined at the beginning of 2016.

    Growth and inflation and foreign demand and exchange rate

    Of goods and services.

    Central Bureau of Statistics; OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367914

    The lack of macroeconomic leeway highlights the need for structural reform

    The Bank of Israel has kept its policy interest rate at 0.10% since March 2015 and has continued to intervene on the currency market. Since the end of 2015, it has incorporated forward guidance on monetary policy into its communication, according to which policy is set to remain accommodating for a considerable time. Despite having stabilised in recent months, the shekel has appreciated by over 5% in effective terms compared to the first quarter of 2015. Long-term interest rates remain low, while property prices have risen by 7% year on year.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369327

    The public deficit fell to 2.1% of GDP in 2015, but is expected rise to 2.9% of GDP in 2016, which will support growth. Lower business taxes and increased public spending, especially on welfare and housing, will make the economy more inclusive. As of 2017, however, it would be appropriate to resume the public debt reduction strategy. On a structural level, the steps taken to open the agricultural and food sector to imports and the banking sector to new competitors will generate benefits in terms of higher productivity and wages, and will help reduce the cost of living. Social cohesion, employment and productivity would also be encouraged by a better public transport network and improved training for underprivileged groups, currently poorly integrated into the labour market.

    The economy should pick up gradually

    Domestic demand is projected to remain the main driver of growth. Accommodative monetary policy, the fiscal easing in 2016 and low oil prices should sustain consumption spending, while investment should continue to benefit from new project launches in the technology sector and government measures to stimulate house building. External demand is set to recover only slowly, as the high exchange rate holds back exports. Thereafter growth could gradually pick up to reach its potential in 2017, but some economic slack will persist. In these conditions, unemployment will stay low, as will inflation, which will rise only slowly.

    Global economic prospects, notably in China and Europe, remain volatile and external developments could have a large effect on the Israeli economy. The strong rise in housing prices, despite the authorities' efforts to reverse the trend, is also adding to the risks and to pressure on monetary policy. And failure to find a solution to the problems in developing Leviathan, the offshore gas field, would also hit the Israeli economy, especially if global energy prices rebound.

    Italy

    GDP growth is expected to reach 1% in 2016 and 1.4% in 2017. Private consumption continues to be the main driver of the recovery. Employment growth has temporarily slowed but real income gains and pent-up demand are supporting household spending. Investment is turning around, providing some support to domestic demand, but constraints on the availability of bank credit still impede a faster investment recovery.

    The government has reiterated its commitment to fiscal consolidation, but at a gradual pace, and to the structural reform programme. To generate the fiscal space for a much needed increase in public investment and avert the hike in indirect taxes programmed for 2017, it plans to use EU budget flexibility rules and to contain public spending. ECB monetary policy support and gradual fiscal consolidation have stabilised the debt‑to-GDP ratio, which should start decreasing in 2017.

    The collapse of investment in the wake of the crisis has exacerbated a long‑standing labour productivity slowdown. Policy priorities to raise productivity involve speeding up the resolution of banks' non-performing loans, improving the selection process and execution of public infrastructure projects, raising public administration efficiency, and enhancing business dynamism and innovation.

    The recovery continues to rely on private demand

    Consumer and business confidence have retreated from their post-crisis peaks but remain high. Net real household income gains, driven by rising nominal income, low inflation and fiscal measures, along with pent-up demand, especially for transport vehicles and other durable goods, are sustaining private consumption despite the recent slowdown in employment growth. Producer price deflation, mainly due to declining prices of energy and petroleum-based products, weak inflation expectations and still large spare capacity are exerting downward pressures on consumer price inflation.

    Private consumption and inflation

    All items less food, energy, alcohol and tobacco.

    Headline refers to the harmonised index of consumer prices.

    Industry (excluding construction).

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database and ISTAT.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367929

    After a slowdown in late 2015, the recovery is set to regain strength, driven by private consumption and, to a lesser extent, by a moderate investment recovery. Industrial production is trending up, with recent gains attributable to a large extent to capital and consumer durable goods. The increase in capital goods production and the trough reached in the construction sector indicate that investment may finally be turning around. However, bank credit supply constraints, along with uncertainty about future demand conditions, hinder a strong recovery of investment. The government is paving the way to create a secondary market for non-performing loans and improve banks' balance sheets, an important precondition to raise credit supply and investment. Sluggish external demand has been holding back export growth, while robust private consumption has been sustaining import growth.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369052

    Boosting productivity is key to propelling output growth

    The budget deficit declined to 2.6% of GDP in 2015 and is projected to decrease further, largely as a result of the cyclical recovery and low interest rates. The government plans to contain public spending and fully use the flexibility available under EU deficit rules, equivalent to about 0.8% of GDP, to raise public investment, slightly lower taxes and avert a hike in indirect taxes previously programmed for 2017. Rationalising and reducing public spending is a priority, but it will depend in part on raising public-administration efficiency. Permanently lowering social security contributions, especially for those on low salaries, coupled with effective active labour market policies, and shifting the tax burden towards consumption and real estate, based on updated cadastral value, would lay the foundations for a stronger and more equitable growth.

    Production and labour productivity

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and ISTAT.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367938

    Progress on the structural reform programme is contributing to strengthening long‑term growth prospects, but more needs to be done to boost productivity and inclusiveness. The National Agency for Active Labour Market Polices, established under the Jobs Act to coordinate and evaluate activation policies, will be key to bringing more people into good jobs and reduce job-skill mismatch – but it has yet to become operational. Reducing youth unemployment, which is still high, will hinge on better coordinating education and labour market policies. Fully and rapidly implementing the Good School reform and the Jobs Act would be meaningful steps in the right direction. Strengthening the provision of good quality care for children and the elderly would remove barriers keeping women from fully participating in the labour market.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369061

    Raising the efficiency of the public administration would contribute to higher aggregate productivity. The ongoing, but only partly approved, public administration reform will introduce a more performance-oriented human resource system, rationalise enterprises owned by local authorities, set time limits for administrative procedures concerning large investment projects, and extend the access to public services by electronic means. However, implementation will be crucial. Continuing the efforts to accelerate judicial proceedings is critical as lengthy trials undermine the rule of law and reduce investment.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369077

    Boosting the quantity and quality of public and private investment will be crucial to make the recovery sustainable. Implementing the new public procurement code for construction works, improving and accelerating project selection and execution, and vigorously fighting corruption will enhance the quality of public capital spending. The government has recently approved a decree to shorten the process of debt recovery for new loans and existing ones – if both parties agree. Further steps in reforming bankruptcy procedures might be needed to complement the measures already taken.

    Growth is expected to regain momentum

    GDP growth is projected to rise to 1% this year and 1.4% next year. Rising real household disposable income and improving labour market conditions will buttress private spending. Gross fixed capital formation will continue its gradual recovery and modestly accelerate in 2017. Robust internal demand will result in imports growing faster than exports. Inflation will remain low, reflecting continued product and labour market slack.

    The recovery of investment will depend on the effects of the government's initiatives to remove bad loans from banks’ balance sheets and create a secondary market for them. A faster recovery than anticipated of main trading partners would boost exports and growth. Geopolitical uncertainties in the Mediterranean region remain high; the refugee crisis and the costs it entails will depend on how they evolve. Delays in implementing the ambitious public investment programme and sufficiently cut public expenditure to avoid the hike in indirect taxes, for which Italy successfully invoked EU budget flexibility rules, would slow the recovery and worsen the fiscal position. The event of Brexit and renewed financial market turmoil in the euro area could raise risk spreads, and debt financing costs, requiring more fiscal restraint. Private consumption growth could be lower than projected if the reduction in social-security-contribution exemptions affects employment growth more than expected.

    Japan

    Output growth has been slowed by a drop in demand from China and other Asian countries and by sluggish private consumption. Growth is projected to be around 0.7% in 2016 and 0.4% in 2017, as labour and capacity shortages and record-high corporate profits support business investment, employment and wages. The impact of the consumption tax hike planned for 2017 is expected to be partially offset by a pick-up in exports.

    Raising output growth is essential to reduce the ratio of public debt to GDP, which will reach 234% in 2017. To achieve a primary budget surplus and maintain confidence in Japan’s public finances, it is necessary to implement a more detailed and concrete strategy to reduce spending and raise revenue, including by gradual increases in the consumption tax rate. Continuing the quantitative and qualitative easing policy until the 2% inflation target has been sustainably achieved is also necessary.

    Structural reform to raise productivity is fundamental to long-term growth. Narrowing the productivity gap with the top half of OECD countries requires bold reforms, such as enhancing trade integration through the Trans-Pacific Partnership and other agreements, and increasing business-sector dynamism through improved corporate governance and regulatory reform. Boosting investment in knowledge-based capital, such as vocational education and training, is also essential to spur productivity growth.

    The engines of growth remain in place

    With the working-age population falling more than 1% a year, employment growth has been sustained by higher labour force participation, particularly among women. Nevertheless, labour shortages have risen to their highest levels in 25 years. Although the response of nominal wages to tightening labour market conditions has been weak thus far, real wages are rising, as consumer price inflation has fallen close to zero as a result of the drop in energy prices. The impact of household income gains on private consumption has been limited by a rise in the household saving rate from negative territory in 2013-14 to more than 1% in 2015.

    Fiscal position and industrial production

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry; and Bank of Japan.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367943

    Despite a decline in industrial production, due notably to weaker demand from Asia, business investment rebounded in the second half of 2015, reflecting labour and capacity shortages. Investment is also supported by record high profits and by the cut in the corporate tax rate from 37% in FY 2013 to just under 30% in FY 2016. Consequently, corporate cash holdings have surpassed 60% of GDP. However, the 10% appreciation of the yen relative to the dollar in early 2016 and uncertainty about China’s growth prospects have weakened business confidence.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368957

    Structural reforms are key to boosting growth and achieving fiscal sustainability

    Raising productivity and boosting growth toward the 2% target in the Japan Revitalisation Strategy calls for a wide range of bold reforms. The Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement is a major step and will help Japan shift to a more market-oriented agricultural sector. Additional free trade agreements currently under negotiation, such as Japan-EU and Japan-China-Korea, would also be beneficial. Another key to higher productivity is unlocking the corporate sector’s large cash holdings to boost investment and wages. The priority is to strengthen corporate governance by effective implementation of the recently-introduced Stewardship Code and Corporate Governance Code. Labour productivity also depends on developing the skills demanded in the labour market. Sustaining employment growth and promoting social cohesion require policies to narrow the large employment and wage gaps between men and women, which are among the highest in the OECD, by increasing the availability of affordable, high-quality childcare and promoting work-life balance. In addition, the tax and social contribution systems should be reformed to remove disincentives to work by second earners in households. Breaking down dualism would narrow wage inequality, which is a major cause of income inequality and relative poverty, and make growth more inclusive.

    Real wages and business confidence

    Seasonally-adjusted data based on establishments with thirty or more workers.

    Deflated by the consumer price index, excluding imputed rent.

    Profits of non-financial firms, seasonally-adjusted.

    Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare; and Ministry of Finance.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933367954

    The introduction of negative interest rates in February 2016 reaffirmed the Bank of Japan’s commitment to its 2% inflation target and has helped to push the yield on long-term government bonds into negative territory. The Bank continues to expand the monetary base by 80 trillion yen (16% of GDP) per year through its qualitative and quantitative easing. Nevertheless, headline consumer price inflation (excluding the tax hike), which peaked in mid-2014 at 1½ per cent (year-on-year), has remained close to zero since mid-2015, reflecting the decline in oil prices. Excluding food and energy, inflation has been nearly 1% in recent months.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368969

    The general government primary deficit, which fell from 7.8% of GDP in 2013 to 4.8% in 2015, is projected to narrow further to 3¾ per cent in 2017 due to the consumption tax hike planned for that year and the continued fall in reconstruction spending. Depending on economic conditions, well-timed fiscal stimulus may be needed to mitigate the impact of the 2017 tax hike. However, even with the planned measures, Japan is not on track to achieve its target of a primary surplus (central and local governments) by FY 2020. A more detailed and concrete fiscal strategy should include measures to contain the growth of social spending and boost revenue through a gradual increase in the consumption tax rate, a broadening of the personal and corporate income tax bases and higher environmental taxes, which would also promote green growth.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368972

    The expansion is projected to continue at a moderate pace through 2017

    Output growth is projected to be around 0.7% in 2016 and 0.4% in 2017, supported by a gradual pick-up in wages, notably for non-regular workers and employees in SMEs. The quarterly growth pattern, though, is likely to be volatile due to the consumption tax hike. As in 2013-14, rush demand is expected to boost private consumption through the first quarter of 2017, followed by a decline after the tax hike. Weaker private consumption is projected to be partially offset by a pick-up in export growth as world trade rebounds, which will support business investment. Assuming broadly stable oil prices, headline inflation is projected to converge toward core inflation, reaching around 1% (excluding the tax hike) in 2017.

    External indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368983

    Sustained output growth depends on a virtuous circle of rising prices, wages and corporate earnings. The major uncertainty pertains to wages; while wage stagnation is a major downside risk, faster-than-expected gains would lead to stronger private consumption. External risks are largely on the downside, given uncertainty about China, which accounts for a quarter of Japanese exports. Continued yen appreciation would lower corporate profits and exports. Japan’s unprecedentedly high level of public debt is another key risk. Unless Japan implements a more detailed and concrete strategy to achieve its fiscal targets, it could face a loss of confidence in its fiscal sustainability, which in turn could destabilise the financial sector and the real economy, with large spillovers to the world economy.

    Korea

    Output growth is projected to be 2.7% in 2016, reflecting weak external demand and fiscal tightening, with inflation around 1%. With stronger external demand in 2017, growth is projected to pick up to about 3%, in line with potential. The current account surplus will remain high at 7½ per cent of GDP.

    Government spending is set to rise less than 1% in 2016. Given its budget surplus and low debt, Korea should introduce a supplementary budget to provide some stimulus. Inflation has undershot the target since 2012, suggesting scope to cut the policy interest rate, although the central bank needs to take high household debt and the risk of capital outflows into account.

    Korea’s labour productivity growth was the fastest in the OECD during the past 25 years, but the level of labour productivity is still only 55% of the average of the top half of OECD countries, reflecting weak productivity in services. Product market regulation is among the most stringent in the OECD area. The government is addressing the causes of low productivity through its Three-year Plan for Economic Innovation launched in 2014. Policies to break down labour market dualism would encourage firm-based training, thereby boosting productivity.

    Output growth faces some headwinds

    The strong rebound in the second half of 2015, supported by fiscal stimulus, faltered in early 2016 as private consumption declined. Weak demand from China, which accounts for a quarter of Korean exports, continues to constrain export growth.
