Recent wage settlements foreshadow only moderate wage growth despite tightening labour markets. Consumption is growing moderately too, in part because increases in disposable incomes are being funnelled into savings and housing. Ultra-loose monetary policy continues as inflation shows signs of picking up only modestly, boosting house prices and household borrowing.

    GDP growth and migration

    Working day adjusted.

    Excluding immigrants from European Economic Area countries.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; Swedish Migration Agency.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368121

    Further policy measures are required to strengthen sustainable and inclusive growth

    Strong government revenue growth will be partly offset by increasing spending related to migration. The government is considering moving from targeting a surplus over the cycle to budget balance, which is appropriate given Sweden’s relatively low public debt. Gradually increasing inflation weaken the case for further rate cuts, following the cut in the repo rate from -0.35% to -0.50% in mid-February.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369440

    Strong population growth, low interest rates, favourable tax treatment of property and a slow supply response have led to double-digit house price increases for the past two years, and to higher household indebtedness. The authorities have taken new macro-prudential measures and steps to increase housing supply. Easing planning and rental regulations would support supply. Phasing out mortgage interest deductibility would damp price increases, improve capital allocation and be positive for income and wealth distribution.

    Productivity is high in Sweden, but has grown sluggishly for a decade, despite a recent uptick. Sweden is strongly integrated in global value chains and has specialised in high value-added knowledge-based activities, such as design and marketing. High and equitably distributed skills drive productivity and inclusiveness, but the low-skilled struggle to gain a toe-hold in the labour market. Falling school results need to be addressed, and migrants need to be better integrated through language training, up-skilling and support for employment.

    Steaming ahead, but at a slower pace

    Modest increases in wages should lead to moderate real income and consumption growth. Private investment, notably in housing, will continue to grow strongly, albeit at a slowing pace as capacity utilisation rises. Expansionary monetary policy and diminishing labour market slack are projected to drive inflation gradually up towards the target. Public consumption and tax revenues will grow strongly, resulting in a balanced budget. So will foreign trade, with a steady increase of both imports and exports.

    As a small, open economy strongly integrated into global value chains, Sweden is particularly exposed to developments in its trading partners, including China and the United Kingdom. Currency movements, notably vis-à-vis the euro and the Norwegian krone, would impact output. With policy rates set to stay low for some time, a failure to rein in household debt could result in unbalanced growth, heightening financial risks and households’ vulnerability to house price declines and interest rate increases.

    Switzerland

    After a weak 2015, economic growth is projected to strengthen gradually as domestic demand receives support from negative interest rates and increasing real wages. With the currency stabilising over recent months and oil prices recovering, consumer prices should turn up during 2017. After a recent rise, unemployment will start to fall in 2017, but the outsized current account surplus will persist.

    The budgetary situation is sufficiently sound to withstand a downturn or any foreseeable medium-term challenges. Monetary policy settings are appropriate, but continued vigilance on the housing market is required. The government needs to be careful in implementing immigration quotas to avoid damaging its relationship with the European Union.

    While the level of labour productivity is high, its slow growth over the past decade should be actively addressed. Competition in the telecoms and energy sectors needs to be sharpened. Support to agriculture should be further curtailed, and more free-trade agreements should be concluded. Greater female market employment should be promoted to increase inclusiveness and ensure that womens’ skills are utilised fully.

    The economy is recovering gradually

    Economic growth has shown signs of picking up after a weak outcome last year. The negative effects of the sharp exchange rate appreciation in January 2015 are fading, and exchange rate stability since last summer has contributed to a rebound in exports. However, some other components of demand are still suffering, including business investment and consumption of durable goods. Employment growth has resumed. Consumer price deflation has persisted through 2015 and thus far in 2016, but in part this has reflected the transitory effects of the sharp oil price declines. Business and household confidence were hit by the 2015 appreciation, but it has now improved notably in manufacturing. The persistently large current account surplus, which averaged almost 11½ per cent of GDP in 2015, dropped in the fourth quarter, owing to a fall in primary income.

    Labour productivity and debt mortgage

    Contribution to trend labour productivity growth rate.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 Database; and IMF, Financial Soundness Indicators.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368134

    Monetary policy will remain accommodative, and structural policy could help revive the economy

    The very accommodative monetary stance is appropriate, given still negative inflation and the intermediate objective of avoiding an appreciation of the franc. However, macro‑prudential policy may need to be reinforced as mortgage debt is extremely high, even if borrowing costs will stay very low for the foreseeable future. Fiscal policy is slightly contractionary, with the budget nearly balanced and public indebtedness stable at modest levels. While the debt brake rule has helped in the past, it should not be allowed to block a fiscal expansion if that is needed.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369459

    While Switzerland benefits from a relatively high level of labour productivity, the recent slowdown is worrying. Competition in the energy and telecoms sectors should be increased and direct payments to agriculture curtailed. Growth prospects would also improve if more women, many of whom now work part-time, were fully included in the labour force and market employment. Reducing the cost of childcare and reforming second-earner taxation would remove impediments to full-time work and make it easier to reconcile careers and home life. Pushing forward with free-trade agreements – particularly with India and the United States – would favour growth. Immigration of highly-skilled workers has contributed to past productivity performance but is now endangered by the imposition of quotas scheduled for 2017.

    Output growth will resume, but with significant uncertainties related to the European Union

    Strengthening private consumption and business investment are projected to contribute significantly to output increases. The unemployment rate is projected to decline, but only slightly as the trade-exposed sector continues to suffer from the weak global environment and the strong Swiss franc. Low, but positive, inflation is set to return in 2017 as external deflationary factors dissipate. The external surplus is set to edge down on the back of a shrinking primary income balance.

    A prolonged sluggish global recovery, especially in Europe, would hurt growth. Financial turmoil in Europe or further monetary easing by the ECB would put upward pressure on the Swiss franc, hurting exports. A failure of negotiations with the European Union regarding immigration quotas constitutes a serious risk to the economy. A more pronounced rebound in global trade than projected would be a boost.

    Turkey

    GDP growth is projected to remain close to 4% per annum in 2016 and 2017. A sharp hike in the minimum wage and social transfers in early 2016 will boost private consumption. However, the associated increase in labour costs, despite subsidies to alleviate them in the first year, will hurt competitiveness and exports. As the short-run impact of the jump in household income wanes, growth is projected to edge down in 2017.

    Business and household confidence remain frail in the context of severe regional geopolitical tensions and a difficult domestic political climate. The implementation of the key provisions of the 2016 Action Plan, which entails convergence towards OECD good practices in many areas, would improve both domestic and international confidence, and support investment and growth.

    Productivity is undermined by the fragmentation of the business sector. Efficient firms cannot grow at full potential due to shortcomings in the regulatory framework. At the same time, low-productivity entities, which employ a large share of the low-skilled, survive thanks to the incomplete enforcement of rules and regulations. The resulting stalemate calls for a comprehensive upgrading of the business environment and skills, to foster the shift of resources from low to higher-productivity firms.

    Strong growth has been driven by domestic demand

    GDP growth has been strong since early 2015, driven by private consumption. The deterioration of household confidence amid domestic political uncertainties and severe regional conflicts has not held back consumption. Household spending remained robust, boosted by promises of a large hike in the minimum wage and increases in social transfers. The influx of refugees from Syria also stimulated demand. In contrast, private business investment stayed subdued.

    Consumption and confidence and GDP growth

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and Turkish Statistical Institute.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368148

    Exports remained weak due to a sharp contraction in regional markets, despite competitiveness gains stemming from exchange rate depreciation through 2015. As of January-February 2016, exports to Russia had fallen by 63% year-on-year and exports to Iraq by 21%. At the same time, exporters of manufactured goods gained market share in the EU and US markets. Still, total goods and services exports declined in volume in 2015, while the current account deficit fell owing to the sharp drop in oil prices. The Russian embargo on Turkey’s exports from January 2016 heralds further contraction of the Russian market, notably for tourism which accounts for 7% of total employment. Foreign funding needs, which will approach 20% of GDP in 2016, have so far been financed smoothly by capital inflows.

    Demand, output and prices

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369464

    Macroeconomic policies are supportive in the short term

    At least 30% of wage earners earn the minimum wage, so the 30% minimum wage hike granted in January and increases in other social transfers are giving a significant boost to private consumption. But they are also heightening pressures on inflation, which had reached 8.8% at the end of 2015 before declining to 7.5% at the end of the first quarter thanks to favourable food prices and a stronger exchange rate. Despite competitiveness losses induced by the minimum wage jump, business confidence was helped by a Government Action Plan announced in early 2016 which included important structural reform objectives in labour and product markets. If fully implemented, this programme should support firms in the formal sector and thereby create higher-productivity and better-paid jobs. At the same time, tensions in the Eastern regions, persisting geopolitical strains across borders and terrorist attacks in early 2016 have affected general confidence.

    Macroeconomic policies are supportive in the short term, and the projection assumes that the new government will stick to the basic orientations of the Medium-Term Economic Programme published in January. The fiscal stance will be expansionary in 2016 with the fulfilment of election promises, but spending restraint is planned from 2017, with the share of general government spending in GDP inching back down to 41%. Monetary policy was loosened between February and April in the context of supportive global financing conditions, with a decline in the average funding rate of the central bank and cuts in the upper end of the interest-rate corridor. Macro-prudential policies were slightly relaxed, facilitating the use of credit cards for certain categories of consumer purchases.

    Risks are significant on both sides

    Annual growth is projected to approach 4% in 2016 and to edge down in 2017. Inflation is projected to be just under 8% in the second half of 2016, well above the target of 5%, before subsiding somewhat in 2017. If the intended structural reforms proceed, and domestic political and regional geopolitical conditions improve, stronger private investment and exports may propel growth to higher levels. The projection, however, is conditional on political stability and assumes that the key orientations of the existing medium-term economic framework are retained. If not, or if regional and domestic tensions were to intensify, domestic demand and tourism would be adversely affected. Any associated weakening in international confidence may trigger capital outflows and exchange-rate volatility, weighing on short-term growth. In addition, Turkey is exposed to global risks arising from China’s prospects and from the expected normalisation of US monetary policy and would be negatively affected by a slowdown in Europe.

    United Kingdom

    Growth has slowed, and is projected to be 1¾ per cent in 2016. Uncertainty about the outcome of the end-June 2016 referendum, which could lead to an exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union (Brexit), has undermined growth. This projection assumes that the United Kingdom remains in the European Union, in which case growth is projected to pick up in the second half of 2016 and then stabilise in 2017. The unemployment rate has fallen to around 5%. The current account deficit has reached 7% of GDP, the highest level on record, increasing vulnerabilities.

    Fiscal consolidation is planned to continue, but its pace will ease to below 1% of GDP per year over the projection horizon, which is appropriate given a weaker economic outlook. Capacity pressures have abated and should remain contained, but the recent exchange rate depreciation will push up prices. This projection assumes interest rate normalisation will start in early 2017.

    Productivity has been exceptionally weak since 2007, and reviving it is essential to sustain growth and living standards. Fiscal decentralisation and greater infrastructure investment would support capital stock accumulation and better use of resources. Better matching of skills to jobs and higher skill levels would also lift productivity. Financial conditions have improved for businesses, but as markets tighten more rapid exit of non-viable businesses would make room for new, more innovative businesses.

    Economic activity has weakened

    Following recent robust GDP growth driven by vibrant domestic demand, rising uncertainty about the outcome of the referendum on the membership of the United Kingdom in the European Union, and a possible exit (Brexit), has led to a significant slowdown in economic activity. Business investment has contracted as businesses have put their spending decisions on hold and hiring intentions have weakened. Financial markets have also increasingly started to price in the risk of Brexit. The exchange rate has fallen and the cost of protection against its future volatility has increased. Equity prices have so far been resilient, as many listed companies are global, but rising investors’ fears have pushed up the cost of protection against sovereign default.

    GDP growth and current account

    The newspaper-based economic policy uncertainty index is constructed based on the number of articles that appear in The Times of London and the Financial Times and refer to economic policy uncertainty. It is normalised to a mean of 100 prior to 2011.

    National Institute of Economic and Social Research; www.policyuncertainty.com; and OECD Economic Outlook 99 database.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368159

    The labour market has remained strong, with record high participation rates and the unemployment rate falling to about 5%, low by historical standards. However, productivity growth has been sluggish. The current account deficit has increased further, to 7% of GDP, driven by lower returns on external assets relative to the return on domestic assets held by foreigners, and to a lesser extent by further losses of the market share of exports. Consumer price inflation is still weak, but has edged up from recent lows.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369082

    Weak productivity has been holding back wage growth. In April 2016, the new statutory minimum wage for workers aged 25 or more, the National Living Wage, was increased by 7.5%. Further hikes are planned to gradually lift it by about 35%, to 60% of median hourly earnings, by 2020. For those with jobs, this should increase incomes and reduce poverty, but the effects on employment need to be closely monitored. Efforts to improve the skills of low-productivity workers also need to continue, in order for more people to enjoy the benefits of the economic recovery. The authorities plan to support the development of vocational skills by introducing an apprenticeship levy on large businesses.

    Budget revenue and inflation

    Excludes energy, food, alcohol and tobacco.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and Office for National Statistics.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368161

    The macroeconomic policy mix will continue to shift

    The government has confirmed its commitment to reach a budget surplus of 0.5% of GDP by 2019, mainly by spending reduction. Stripping out cyclical effects, the authorities expect to cut the deficit by around 0.8% of GDP per year in 2016-17. This is less than planned before, which should ease the impact of consolidation on growth. At the same time, monetary policy is set to remain highly supportive, and the first interest rate increase is assumed to take place only in early 2017.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369095

    Persistent very supportive monetary policy risks creating bubbles, and house prices have continued to rise rapidy, reducing affordability, notably in London. In response, the Bank of England has raised counter-cyclical capital requirements. However, there is also a need to boost housing supply by relaxing planning regulations in order to make housing more affordable again.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369106

    Further policy reforms could help to strengthen aggregate productivity performance and better spread the advantages of growth to more people. Stronger infrastructure investment would reduce bottlenecks. Releasing more land for housing would make it possible for more people to afford housing near their jobs thereby reducing skill mismatches, which would improve the quality and productiveness of work. Lending to small and medium sized enterprises has started to recover, which is positive for the emergence of new high-growth and innovative businesses, but it is also important to support corporate restructuring. The government has started important reforms to transfer greater responsibilities to major cities, which is welcome as local governments can be more responsive to people’s needs and it may help to raise productivity and incomes in lagging regions.

    External indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933369114

    Growth is projected to pick up after the referendum

    This projection assumes that the United Kingdom remains in the European Union. Growth is set to be weak and volatile in the first half of 2016 owing to the impact of the referendum on spending decisions, mainly of businesses. However, GDP growth will strengthen in the second half of 2016 as uncertainty dissipates, and stabilise at 2% in 2017. This growth will be enough to keep the unemployment rate low.

    The outcome of the referendum is a major risk for the economy. A vote for Brexit would heighten uncertainty, raise the cost of finance and hamper investment. According to OECD estimates, GDP growth could be lower by 0.5 percentage point in 2017 and 2018 and by 1.5 percentage points in 2019. The Bank of England could stabilise the financial sector through liquidity support, but refinancing of public debt could become more costly. The large current account deficit may also be harder to finance, which could force a costly adjustment. Higher productivity growth would sustain economic activity and wages, and improve public finances more than projected. Stronger demand from the euro area would limit the extent of the current account deficit by supporting exports, but this could be offset by further headwinds from emerging markets.

    United States

    Despite a recent soft patch reflecting transitory factors, output remains on a moderate growth trajectory sustained by mutually-reinforcing gains in employment, income and household spending. Steady job gains have pushed down the unemployment rate, and recently the labour force has risen. Moderate output gains are likely to resume as these influences wane, with solid domestic demand growth counteracted by relatively sluggish gains in external demand.

    Monetary policy is very accommodative, consistent with below-target inflation, weak nominal wage pressures and subdued inflation expectations. The Federal Reserve raised its policy rates last December by ¼ percentage point, and this projection assumes they inch up to 1½ per cent by end-2017 in the context of weak inflationary pressures and asymmetric downside risks to the inflation outlook. Fiscal policy is projected to be roughly neutral in 2016 and 2017. Public debt prospects have improved, but the debt-to-GDP ratio will remain high without higher growth or further consolidation.

    Productivity growth has been especially slow in recent years, intensifying a broad-based deceleration initiated in the early 2000s. Although cyclical weakness in demand has contributed to the slowdown, there are signs that structural forces are undermining allocative efficiency, including declines in business dynamism, signs of diminished competitive pressures, and sagging public infrastructure provision. Multiple policies to reinvigorate productivity would be appropriate, such as targeted investments in public infrastructure, eliminating needless inter-jurisdictional differences in occupational licensing, and broadening the scope of antitrust laws.

    GDP growth hit a soft patch at the turn of the year

    The US recovery has generally outpaced most OECD countries, with activity now nearing potential and employment on a steady upward trend. However, in late 2015 and early 2016, activity was weighed down by transitory pressures, including an inventory investment correction and the drag on net exports from earlier strengthening in the dollar. Recent softness may also reflect measurement difficulties, as a recurring pattern of early-year lurches in real GDP growth has eluded seasonal adjustments (which are applied to the individual data series used to construct aggregate expenditures and not to the aggregates themselves). Transitory fluctuations aside, domestic demand is being supported by income from steady job gains, which is boosting household consumption and new housing demand. However, business investment has been lacklustre, in part because of sustained downward pressure on drilling and mining investment from low oil prices, and the drag on final demand from weak external markets.

    Stockbuilding and oil price

    Measured by inventories to final sales ratio.

    WTI oil price divided by GDP deflator.

    OECD calculations using NIPA estimates.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368177

    Labour market slack continues to narrow. The unemployment rate has been hovering near estimates of the natural rate for some time, and the participation rate has recently climbed toward its estimated structural level. But these structural levels are measured imprecisely, and signs of slack remain for less-skilled workers (a group tilted toward lower wage earners such as teenagers and ethnic minorities), workers employed part-time for economic reasons, and some other groups. In any case, acceleration in nominal compensation per hour has so far been weak. With the labour market expected to tighten further, wage growth is likely to strengthen, which will provide welcome support to household income and consumer spending. Wage acceleration would be particularly supportive if it boosted earnings for those at the lower end of the earnings distribution.

    Employment, income and inflation

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368918

    The policy environment remains supportive

    With little sign that narrowing slack is pushing up inflation, the Federal Reserve is assumed to raise policy rates very gradually to 1½ per cent by end-2017, if data come in as projected. This will leave interest rates supportive throughout the projection, which is broadly appropriate given weak inflationary pressures as well as asymmetric risks to the outlook posed by the ongoing weakness of global demand and the diminished capacity of policy to respond to negative shocks.

    Labour productivity and market concentration

    Real GDP per hour worked.

    Six-digit NAICS industries.

    OECD Economic Outlook 99 database; and OECD calculations using quinquennial Economic Census.

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368189

    The impetus from fiscal policy is assumed to remain roughly neutral over the projection. General government gross debt stabilises near 114% of GDP in 2016 as the maturing recovery drives down the overall deficit. In December, Congress made permanent a number of tax incentives—including credits for renewable energy generation and research and development—that had previously been extended annually, thus eliminating delays and uncertainty. The deceleration in health outlays has made fiscal consolidation less urgent for now, but federal debt is still elevated by historical standards and could be placed on an unsustainable course by fiscal indiscipline or by further sluggish productivity growth.

    Financial indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368926

    Productivity growth has been unusually weak throughout the recovery. This partly reflects unusual cyclical employment dynamics, with outsized layoffs in the crisis aftermath followed by unusually strong hiring thereafter, and with capital accumulation restrained by sluggish post-crisis aggregate demand. Even so, productivity has suffered a broad-based deceleration since the early-to-mid 2000s, and this may owe to structural forces that are undermining allocative efficiency – such as diminished business dynamism, weaker competitive pressures, and sagging public infrastructure. These same structural forces may be contributing to widening and persistent income inequality as well. A multi-pronged strategy to reinvigorate productivity would be appropriate, including targeted infrastructure investments to stimulate aggregate demand and improve efficiency, as well as structural measures such as broadening the scope of antitrust laws and eliminating needless variations in occupational licensing across jurisdictions.

    Demand and output

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368939

    GDP is projected to return to a moderate growth trajectory

    GDP is projected to resume its moderate growth trajectory over the remainder of 2016 and in 2017 as transitory downward pressures on domestic demand and net exports play out. Domestic demand strengthens, on balance, as inventory investment flattens, oil drilling fades as a share of GDP, and business investment re-accelerates to rates in line with activity. Exports are also projected to strengthen as the drag from previous dollar appreciation wanes and export markets pick up. Household spending gradually loses vigour as the boost to real disposable income from wage acceleration is insufficient to offset the deceleration in employment as demographic pressures on labour market participation increasingly bind.

    External indicators

    Statlink http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/888933368944

    Risks surround this outlook. Wages could accelerate more forcefully than expected, igniting inflationary pressures. Alternatively, relatively weak demand conditions could be more sustained than expected, unleashing a more intense drag from net exports and production as well as disinflationary pressures. Hourly labour compensation could also fail to accelerate, which could endanger the recovery if coupled with a deceleration in employment from demographic pressures. Remaining slack in the labour market could be substantially wider than thought, implying less inflationary pressure and a more gradual normalisation of monetary policy.

    NOTE ON QUARTERLY PROJECTIONS

    OECD quarterly projections are on a seasonal and working-day-adjusted basis for selected key variables. This implies that differences between adjusted and unadjusted annual data may occur, though these in general are quite small. In some countries, official forecasts of annual figures do not include working-day adjustments. Even when official forecasts do adjust for working days, the size of the adjustment may in some cases differ from that used by the OECD.
